title: Effect sizes for ANOVAs
text: context ANOVA-like tests, common report ANOVA-like effect sizes. Unlike standardized parameters, effect sizes represent amount variance explained model’s terms, term can represented 1 parameters. example, following case, parameters treatment term represent specific contrasts factor’s levels (treatment groups) - difference level reference level (obk.long == 'control'). can also ask overall effect treatment - much variation dependent variable value can predicted (explained ) variation treatment groups. question can answered ANOVA test: can see, variance value (sums--squares, SS) split pieces: part associated treatment. unexplained part (Residual-SS). can now ask percent total variance value associated treatment. measure called Eta-squared (written \(\eta^2\)): \[ \eta^2 = \frac{SS_{effect}}{SS_{total}} = \frac{72.23}{72.23 + 250.96} = 0.22 \] can accessed via eta_squared() function:
code: data(obk.long, package = "afex") # modify the data slightly for the demonstration: obk.long <- obk.long[1:240 %% 3 == 0, ] obk.long$id <- seq_len(nrow(obk.long))  m <- lm(value ~ treatment, data = obk.long)  parameters::model_parameters(m) > Parameter     | Coefficient |   SE |       95% CI | t(77) |      p > ------------------------------------------------------------------ > (Intercept)   |        4.28 | 0.36 | [3.56, 5.00] | 11.85 | < .001 > treatment [A] |        1.97 | 0.54 | [0.89, 3.05] |  3.64 | < .001 > treatment [B] |        2.09 | 0.47 | [1.15, 3.03] |  4.42 | < .001 >  > Uncertainty intervals (equal-tailed) and p values (two-tailed) computed using a >   Wald t-distribution approximation. parameters::model_parameters(anova(m)) > Parameter | Sum_Squares | df | Mean_Square |     F |      p > ----------------------------------------------------------- > treatment |       72.23 |  2 |       36.11 | 11.08 | < .001 > Residuals |      250.96 | 77 |        3.26 |       |        >  > Anova Table (Type 1 tests) library(effectsize)  eta_squared(m, partial = FALSE) > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) >  > Parameter | Eta2 |       95% CI > ------------------------------- > treatment | 0.22 | [0.09, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].

title: Effect sizes for ANOVAs
text: add terms model, can ask two different questions percent variance explained predictor - much variance accounted predictor total, much accounted controlling predictors. latter questions answered partial-Eta squared (\(\eta^2_p\)), percent partial variance (accounting predictors model) associated term: \[ \eta^2_p = \frac{SS_{effect}}{SS_{effect} + SS_{error}} \] can also accessed via eta_squared() function: (phase repeated-measures variable, simplicity modeled .) calculation , SSs computed sequentially - SS phase computed controlling gender, SS treatment computed controlling gender phase. method sequential SS called also type-test. want, ’s great - however many fields (statistical programs) common use “simultaneous” sums squares (type-II type-III tests), SS computed controlling predictors, regardless order. can done car::Anova(type = ...): \(\eta^2_p\) always larger \(\eta^2\). idea simulate effect size design term interest manipulated. terminology assumes causal relationship predictor outcome, reflects experimental world analyses measures hail; However, \(\eta^2_p\) can also simply seen signal--noise- ratio, uses term’s SS error-term’s SS.[^repeated-measure designs term-specific residual-SS used computation effect size]. (Note one-way fixed-effect designs \(\eta^2 = \eta^2_p\).)
code: m <- lm(value ~ gender + phase + treatment, data = obk.long)  eta_squared(m, partial = FALSE) > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) >  > Parameter |     Eta2 |       95% CI > ----------------------------------- > gender    |     0.03 | [0.00, 1.00] > phase     | 9.48e-03 | [0.00, 1.00] > treatment |     0.25 | [0.11, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. eta_squared(m) # partial = TRUE by default > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) >  > Parameter | Eta2 (partial) |       95% CI > ----------------------------------------- > gender    |           0.04 | [0.00, 1.00] > phase     |           0.01 | [0.00, 1.00] > treatment |           0.26 | [0.12, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. eta_squared(car::Anova(m, type = 2), partial = FALSE) > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type II) >  > Parameter |     Eta2 |       95% CI > ----------------------------------- > gender    |     0.05 | [0.00, 1.00] > phase     | 9.22e-03 | [0.00, 1.00] > treatment |     0.24 | [0.11, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. eta_squared(car::Anova(m, type = 3)) # partial = TRUE by default > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) >  > Parameter | Eta2 (partial) |       95% CI > ----------------------------------------- > gender    |           0.07 | [0.01, 1.00] > phase     |           0.01 | [0.00, 1.00] > treatment |           0.26 | [0.12, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].

title: Effect sizes for ANOVAs
text: Type II type III treat interaction differently. Without going weeds , keep mind using type III SS, important center predictors; numeric variables can done mean-centering predictors; factors can done using orthogonal coding (contr.sum effects-coding) dummy variables (treatment coding, default R). unfortunately makes parameter interpretation harder, SSs associated lower-order term (lower-order interaction) represent SS main effect (treatment coding represent SS simple effects). type-III-effects-coding seems like hassle, can use afex package, takes care behind scenes:
code: # compare m_interaction1 <- lm(value ~ treatment * gender, data = obk.long)  # to: m_interaction2 <- lm(   value ~ treatment * gender,   data = obk.long,   contrasts = list(     treatment = "contr.sum",     gender = "contr.sum"   ) )  eta_squared(car::Anova(m_interaction1, type = 3)) > Type 3 ANOVAs only give sensible and informative results when covariates are >   mean-centered and factors are coded with orthogonal contrasts (such as those >   produced by 'contr.sum', 'contr.poly', or 'contr.helmert', but *not* by the >   default 'contr.treatment'). > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) >  > Parameter        | Eta2 (partial) |       95% CI > ------------------------------------------------ > treatment        |           0.12 | [0.02, 1.00] > gender           |       9.11e-03 | [0.00, 1.00] > treatment:gender |           0.20 | [0.07, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. eta_squared(car::Anova(m_interaction2, type = 3)) > Type 3 ANOVAs only give sensible and informative results when covariates are >   mean-centered and factors are coded with orthogonal contrasts (such as those >   produced by 'contr.sum', 'contr.poly', or 'contr.helmert', but *not* by the >   default 'contr.treatment'). > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) >  > Parameter        | Eta2 (partial) |       95% CI > ------------------------------------------------ > treatment        |           0.27 | [0.13, 1.00] > gender           |           0.12 | [0.03, 1.00] > treatment:gender |           0.20 | [0.07, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. library(afex) m_afex <- aov_car(value ~ treatment * gender + Error(id), data = obk.long) > Contrasts set to contr.sum for the following variables: treatment, gender eta_squared(m_afex) > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) >  > Parameter        | Eta2 (partial) |       95% CI > ------------------------------------------------ > treatment        |           0.27 | [0.13, 1.00] > gender           |           0.12 | [0.03, 1.00] > treatment:gender |           0.20 | [0.07, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].

title: Effect sizes for ANOVAs
text: effect sizes unbiased estimators population’s \(\eta^2\): Omega Squared (\(\omega^2\)) Epsilon Squared (\(\epsilon^2\)), also referred Adjusted Eta Squared. \(\omega^2\) \(\epsilon^2\) (partial counterparts, \(\omega^2_p\) & \(\epsilon^2_p\)) unbiased estimators population’s \(\eta^2\) (\(\eta^2_p\), respectively), especially important small samples. Though \(\omega^2\) popular choice (Albers Lakens 2018), \(\epsilon^2\) analogous adjusted-\(R^2\) (Allen 2017, 382), found less biased (Carroll Nordholm 1975).
code: omega_squared(m_afex) > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) >  > Parameter        | Omega2 (partial) |       95% CI > -------------------------------------------------- > treatment        |             0.24 | [0.10, 1.00] > gender           |             0.10 | [0.02, 1.00] > treatment:gender |             0.17 | [0.05, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. epsilon_squared(m_afex) > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) >  > Parameter        | Epsilon2 (partial) |       95% CI > ---------------------------------------------------- > treatment        |               0.25 | [0.11, 1.00] > gender           |               0.11 | [0.02, 1.00] > treatment:gender |               0.18 | [0.06, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].

title: Effect sizes for ANOVAs
text: Partial Eta squared aims estimating effect size design term interest manipulated, assuming terms also manipulated. However, predictors always manipulated - can observed. cases, can use generalized Eta squared (\(\eta^2_G\)), like \(\eta^2_p\) estimating effect size design term interest manipulated, accounting fact terms manipulated (variance present design). \(\eta^2_G\) useful repeated-measures designs, can estimate within-subject effect size predictor manipulated -subjects (Olejnik Algina 2003).
code: eta_squared(m_afex, generalized = "gender") > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) >  > Parameter        | Eta2 (generalized) |       95% CI > ---------------------------------------------------- > treatment        |               0.21 | [0.08, 1.00] > gender           |               0.10 | [0.02, 1.00] > treatment:gender |               0.18 | [0.06, 1.00] >  > - Observed variables: gender > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].

title: Effect sizes for ANOVAs
text: Finally, forgotten child - Cohen’s \(f\). Cohen’s \(f\) transformation \(\eta^2_p\), ratio term-SS error-SS. \[\text{Cohen's} f_p = \sqrt{\frac{\eta^2_p}{1-\eta^2_p}} = \sqrt{\frac{SS_{effect}}{SS_{error}}}\] can take values zero, population means equal, indefinitely large number means apart. analogous Cohen’s \(d\) two groups.
code: cohens_f(m_afex) > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) >  > Parameter        | Cohen's f (partial) |      95% CI > ---------------------------------------------------- > treatment        |                0.61 | [0.38, Inf] > gender           |                0.37 | [0.17, Inf] > treatment:gender |                0.50 | [0.28, Inf] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [Inf].

text: now ’ve discusses effect sizes fixed-effect linear model repeated-measures ANOVA’s - cases SSs readily available, various effect sized presented can easily estimated. ever always case. example, linear mixed models (LMM/HLM/MLM), estimation required SSs straightforward. However, can still approximate effect sizes (partial versions) based test-statistic approximation method (learn Effect Size Test Statistics vignette). directly `eta_squared() co.: Another case SSs available use Bayesian models. effectsize Bayesian solutions Bayesian models, can read Effect Sizes Bayesian Models vignette.
code: library(lmerTest)  fit_lmm <- lmer(Reaction ~ Days + (Days | Subject), sleepstudy)  anova(fit_lmm) # note the type-3 errors > Type III Analysis of Variance Table with Satterthwaite's method >      Sum Sq Mean Sq NumDF DenDF F value  Pr(>F)     > Days  30031   30031     1    17    45.9 3.3e-06 *** > --- > Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 F_to_eta2(45.8, df = 1, df_error = 17) > Eta2 (partial) |       95% CI > ----------------------------- > 0.73           | [0.51, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. eta_squared(fit_lmm) > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) >  > Parameter | Eta2 (partial) |       95% CI > ----------------------------------------- > Days      |           0.73 | [0.51, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. epsilon_squared(fit_lmm) > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) >  > Parameter | Epsilon2 (partial) |       95% CI > --------------------------------------------- > Days      |               0.71 | [0.48, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. omega_squared(fit_lmm) > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) >  > Parameter | Omega2 (partial) |       95% CI > ------------------------------------------- > Days      |             0.70 | [0.47, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].

title: Effect Sizes for Bayesian Models
text: examine predictive role overtime (xtra_hours), number compliments given boss (n_comps) seniority predicting workers salaries. Let’s fit model: Looking un-standardized (“raw”) parameters, looks like predictors positively predict workers’ salaries, highest predictive power? Unfortunately, predictors scale (hours, compliments, years), comparing hard looking raw data. standardization comes . Like frequentists models can choose standardization methods. Let’s use (slow) "refit" method. Note central tendency posterior distribution still median - median standardized posterior distribution. can easily change , type credible interval used: can see, working harder (least longer hours) stronger predictive power complementing seniority. (note, however, mean wish higher salary work overtime - raw parameters seem suggest complementing boss way go, one compliment worth almost 3.5 times full hours’ work!)
code: library(rstanarm)  data("hardlyworking", package = "effectsize")  head(hardlyworking) >   salary xtra_hours n_comps age seniority > 1  19745        4.2       1  32         3 > 2  11302        1.6       0  34         3 > 3  20636        1.2       3  33         5 > 4  23047        7.2       1  35         3 > 5  27342       11.3       0  33         4 > 6  25657        3.6       2  30         5 mod <- stan_glm(salary ~ xtra_hours + n_comps + seniority,   data = hardlyworking,   prior = normal(0, scale = c(1, 0.5, 0.5), autoscale = TRUE), # set some priors   refresh = 0 )  parameters::model_parameters(mod, test = NULL) > Parameter   |   Median |              95% CI |  Rhat |     ESS |                      Prior > ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- > (Intercept) | 10016.89 | [9190.41, 10871.71] | 1.000 | 5288.00 | Normal (20000 +- 15495.02) > xtra_hours  |  1235.83 | [1175.83,  1292.33] | 1.000 | 4032.00 |      Normal (0 +- 1587.80) > n_comps     |  2962.41 | [2712.00,  3220.75] | 1.000 | 4405.00 |      Normal (0 +- 3755.71) > seniority   |   442.16 | [ 228.84,   637.99] | 1.000 | 4023.00 |      Normal (0 +- 2702.93) >  > Uncertainty intervals (highest-density) and p values (two-tailed) computed >   using a MCMC distribution approximation. library(effectsize)  standardize_parameters(mod, method = "refit", ci = 0.89) > Warning: Standardizing variables without adjusting priors may lead to bogus > results unless priors are auto-scaled. > # Standardization method: refit >  > Parameter   | Median (std.) |        89% CI > ------------------------------------------- > (Intercept) |     -2.63e-04 | [-0.03, 0.03] > xtra_hours  |          0.78 | [ 0.75, 0.81] > n_comps     |          0.39 | [ 0.37, 0.42] > seniority   |          0.08 | [ 0.05, 0.11] library(effectsize)  standardize_parameters(mod,   method = "basic", ci = 0.89,   centrality = "MAP", ci_method = "eti" ) > # Standardization method: basic >  > Parameter   | MAP (std.) |       89% CI > --------------------------------------- > (Intercept) |       0.00 | [0.00, 0.00] > xtra_hours  |       0.78 | [0.75, 0.81] > n_comps     |       0.40 | [0.37, 0.42] > seniority   |       0.08 | [0.05, 0.11]

title: Effect Sizes for Bayesian Models
text: classical frequentists models, computation \(\eta^2\) \(\eta^2_p\) straightforward: based right combinations sums--squares (SSs), get correct proportion variance accounted predictor term. However computation straightforward Bayesian models, various reasons (e.g., model-SS residual-SS don’t necessarily sum total-SS). Although proposed Bayesian methods estimating explained variance ANOVA designs (Marsman et al. 2019), yet easy implement stan-based models. alternative route obtaining effect sizes explained variance, via use posterior predictive distribution (PPD). PPD Bayesian expected distribution possible unobserved values. Thus, observing data, can estimate just expected mean values (conditional marginal means), also full distribution data around values (Gelman et al. 2014, chap. 7). sampling PPD, can decompose sample various SSs needed computation explained variance measures. repeatedly sampling PPD, can generate posterior distribution explained variance estimates. note estimates conditioned location-parameters model, also scale-parameters model! vital validate PPD using estimate explained variance measures.

title: Effect Sizes for Bayesian Models
text: Let’s factorize data : fit model: can use eta_squared_posterior() get posterior distribution \(eta^2\) \(eta^2_p\) effect. Like ANOVA table, must make sure use right effects-coding SS-type: Compare :
code: hardlyworking$age_f <- cut(hardlyworking$age,   breaks = c(25, 35, 45), right = FALSE,   labels = c("Young", "Less_young") ) hardlyworking$comps_f <- cut(hardlyworking$n_comps,   breaks = c(0, 1, 2, 3),   include.lowest = TRUE,   right = FALSE )  table(hardlyworking$age_f, hardlyworking$comps_f) >              >              [0,1) [1,2) [2,3] >   Young        124   188   114 >   Less_young    13    34    27 # use (special) effects coding contrasts(hardlyworking$age_f) <- bayestestR::contr.orthonorm contrasts(hardlyworking$comps_f) <- bayestestR::contr.orthonorm  modAOV <- stan_glm(salary ~ age_f * comps_f,   data = hardlyworking, family = gaussian(),   refresh = 0 ) pes_posterior <- eta_squared_posterior(modAOV,   draws = 500, # how many samples from the PPD?   partial = TRUE, # partial eta squared   # type 3 SS   ss_function = car::Anova, type = 3,    verbose = FALSE )  head(pes_posterior) >    age_f comps_f age_f:comps_f > 1 0.0070   0.139       0.00435 > 2 0.0096   0.111       0.01402 > 3 0.0402   0.136       0.00965 > 4 0.0044   0.185       0.03981 > 5 0.0500   0.076       0.00204 > 6 0.0822   0.072       0.00066 bayestestR::describe_posterior(pes_posterior,    rope_range = c(0, 0.1), test = "rope" ) > Summary of Posterior Distribution >  > Parameter     | Median |       95% CI |         ROPE | % in ROPE > ---------------------------------------------------------------- > age_f         |   0.03 | [0.00, 0.07] | [0.00, 0.10] |      100% > comps_f       |   0.13 | [0.06, 0.21] | [0.00, 0.10] |    17.86% > age_f:comps_f |   0.01 | [0.00, 0.04] | [0.00, 0.10] |      100% modAOV_f <- lm(salary ~ age_f * comps_f,   data = hardlyworking )  eta_squared(car::Anova(modAOV_f, type = 3)) > Type 3 ANOVAs only give sensible and informative results when covariates are >   mean-centered and factors are coded with orthogonal contrasts (such as those >   produced by 'contr.sum', 'contr.poly', or 'contr.helmert', but *not* by the >   default 'contr.treatment'). > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) >  > Parameter     | Eta2 (partial) |       95% CI > --------------------------------------------- > age_f         |           0.03 | [0.01, 1.00] > comps_f       |           0.13 | [0.09, 1.00] > age_f:comps_f |       6.65e-03 | [0.00, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].

what: Converting Between d, r, and OR
title: Converting Between Indices of Effect Size
text: basic conversion r values, measure standardized association two continuous measures, d values (Cohen’s d), measure standardized differences two groups / conditions. Let’s simulate data: can compute Cohen’s d two groups: can also treat 2-level group variable numeric variable, compute Pearson’s r: summary statistics? Say, \(d=-0.37\) want know r ? can approximate r using following formula (Borenstein et al. 2009): \[ r \approx \frac{d}{\sqrt{d^2 + 4}} \] indeed, use d_to_r(), get pretty decent approximation: (also works way, r_to_d(0.17) gives -0.345) can see, rough approximations, can useful don’t raw data hand.
code: set.seed(1) data <- bayestestR::simulate_difference(   n = 10,   d = 0.2,   names = c("Group", "Outcome") ) >    Group Outcome > 1      0  -0.942 > 2      0  -0.485 > 3      0  -0.100 > 4      0   0.285 > 5      0   0.742 > 6      1  -0.742 > 7      1  -0.285 > 8      1   0.100 > 9      1   0.485 > 10     1   0.942 cohens_d(Outcome ~ Group, data = data) > Cohen's d |        95% CI > ------------------------- > -0.31     | [-1.54, 0.95] >  > - Estimated using pooled SD. correlation::correlation(data, include_factors = TRUE)[2, ] > # Correlation Matrix (pearson-method) >  > Parameter1 | Parameter2 |     r |        95% CI |  t(8) |      p > ---------------------------------------------------------------- > Group.0    |    Outcome | -0.17 | [-0.72, 0.52] | -0.48 | > .999 >  > p-value adjustment method: Holm (1979) > Observations: 10 d_to_r(-0.31) > [1] -0.153

title: Converting Between Indices of Effect Size
text: Although exactly classic Cohen’s d, can also approximate partial-d value (, standardized difference two groups / conditions, variance predictors partilled ). example: can convert semi-d values r values, case represent partial correlation:
code: fit <- lm(mpg ~ am + hp, data = mtcars)  parameters::model_parameters(fit) > Parameter   | Coefficient |       SE |         95% CI | t(29) |      p > ---------------------------------------------------------------------- > (Intercept) |       26.58 |     1.43 | [23.67, 29.50] | 18.65 | < .001 > am          |        5.28 |     1.08 | [ 3.07,  7.48] |  4.89 | < .001 > hp          |       -0.06 | 7.86e-03 | [-0.07, -0.04] | -7.50 | < .001 >  > Uncertainty intervals (equal-tailed) and p values (two-tailed) computed using a >   Wald t-distribution approximation. # A couple of ways to get partial-d: 5.28 / sigma(fit) > [1] 1.81 t_to_d(4.89, df_error = 29)[[1]] > [1] 1.82 t_to_r(4.89, df_error = 29) > r    |       95% CI > ------------------- > 0.67 | [0.43, 0.80] correlation::correlation(mtcars[, c("mpg", "am", "hp")], partial = TRUE)[1, ] > # Correlation Matrix (pearson-method) >  > Parameter1 | Parameter2 |    r |       95% CI | t(30) |         p > ----------------------------------------------------------------- > mpg        |         am | 0.67 | [0.42, 0.83] |  4.97 | < .001*** >  > p-value adjustment method: Holm (1979) > Observations: 32 # all close to: d_to_r(1.81) > [1] 0.671

title: Converting Between Indices of Effect Size
text: Odds ratio, although popular, intuitive interpretations. don’t often think chances catching disease terms odds, instead instead tend think terms probability event - risk. Talking risks can also talk change risk, knows risk ratio (RR). example, find individual suffering migraine, every bowl brussels sprouts eat, ’re odds reducing migraine increase \(= 3.5\) period hour. , people eat brussels sprouts effectively reduce pain? Well, hard say… Maybe look RR ’ll get clue. can convert RR following formula (Grant 2014): \[ RR = \frac{}{(1 - p0 + (p0 \times ))}   \] \(p0\) base-rate risk - probability event without intervention (e.g., probability migraine subsiding within hour without eating brussels sprouts). base-rate risk , say, 85%, get RR : - every bowl brussels sprouts, increase chances reducing migraine mere 12%! worth ? Depends affinity brussels sprouts… Note base-rate risk crucial . instead 85% 4%, RR : - every bowl brussels sprouts, increase chances reducing migraine whopping 318%! worth ? guess still depends affinity brussels sprouts…

title: Effect Sizes: Getting Started
text: theoretical applied research, often interest assess strength observed association. typically done allow judgment magnitude effect (especially units measurement meaningful, e.g., use estimated latent variables; Bollen 1989), facilitate comparing predictors’ importance within given model, . Though indices effect size, correlation coefficient (standardized covariance coefficient) readily available, measures often harder obtain. effectsize R package (R Core Team 2020) fills important gap, providing utilities easily estimating wide variety standardized effect sizes (.e., effect sizes tied units measurement variables interest) confidence intervals (CIs), variety statistical models. effectsize provides easy--use functions, full documentation explanation various effect sizes offered, also used developers R packages back-end effect size computation, parameters (Lüdecke et al. 2020), ggstatsplot (Patil 2018), gtsummary (Sjoberg et al. 2020) .

title: Effect Sizes: Getting Started
text: effectsize’s functionality part comparable packages like lm.beta (Behrendt 2014), MOTE (Buchanan et al. 2019), MBESS (Kelley 2020). Yet, notable differences, e.g.: lm.beta provides standardized regression coefficients linear models, based post-hoc model matrix standardization. However, functionality available limited number models (models inheriting lm class), whereas effectsize provides support many types models, including (generalized) linear mixed models, Bayesian models, . Additionally, additional post-hoc model matrix standardization, effectsize offers methods standardization (see ). MOTE MBESS provide functions computing effect sizes Cohen’s d effect sizes ANOVAs (Cohen 1988), confidence intervals. However, require manual input F- t-statistics, degrees freedom, sums squares computation effect sizes, whereas effectsize can automatically extract information provided models, thus allowing better ease--use well reducing potential error.

title: Effect Sizes: Getting Started
text: Standardizing parameters (.e., coefficients) can allow comparison within models, variables studies. end, two functions available: standardize(), returns updated model, re-fit standardized data, standardize_parameters(), returns table standardized coefficients provided model (list supported models, see insight package; Lüdecke, Waggoner, Makowski 2019). Standardized parameters can also produced generalized linear models (GLMs; predictors standardized): standardize_parameters() provides several standardization methods, robust standardization, pseudo-standardized coefficients (generalized) linear mixed models (Hoffman 2015). full review methods can found Parameter Model Standardization vignette.
code: model <- lm(mpg ~ cyl * am,              data = mtcars)  standardize(model) #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = mpg ~ cyl * am, data = data_std) #>  #> Coefficients: #> (Intercept)          cyl           am       cyl:am   #>     -0.0977      -0.7426       0.1739      -0.1930  standardize_parameters(model) #> # Standardization method: refit #>  #> Parameter   | Coefficient (std.) |         95% CI #> ------------------------------------------------- #> (Intercept) |              -0.10 | [-0.30,  0.11] #> cyl         |              -0.74 | [-0.95, -0.53] #> am          |               0.17 | [-0.04,  0.39] #> cyl:am      |              -0.19 | [-0.41,  0.02] model <- glm(am ~ cyl + hp,              family = "binomial",              data = mtcars)  standardize_parameters(model, exponentiate = TRUE) #> # Standardization method: refit #>  #> Parameter   | Odds Ratio (std.) |        95% CI #> ----------------------------------------------- #> (Intercept) |              0.53 | [0.18,  1.32] #> cyl         |              0.05 | [0.00,  0.29] #> hp          |              6.70 | [1.32, 61.54] #>  #> - Response is unstandardized.

title: Effect Sizes: Getting Started
text: Unlike standardized parameters, effect sizes reported context ANOVAs (analysis variance) ANOVA-like tables represent amount variance explained model’s terms, term can represented one parameters. eta_squared() can produce popular effect sizes Eta-squared (\(\eta^2\)), partial version (\(\eta^2_p\)), well generalized \(\eta^2_G\) (Cohen 1988; Olejnik Algina 2003): effectsize also offers \(\epsilon^2_p\) (epsilon_squared()) \(\omega^2_p\) (omega_squared()), less biased estimates variance explained population (Kelley 1935; Olejnik Algina 2003). details various effect size measures applications, see Effect sizes ANOVAs vignette.
code: options(contrasts = c('contr.sum', 'contr.poly'))  data("ChickWeight") # keep only complete cases and convert `Time` to a factor ChickWeight <- subset(ChickWeight, ave(weight, Chick, FUN = length) == 12) ChickWeight$Time <- factor(ChickWeight$Time)  model <- aov(weight ~ Diet * Time + Error(Chick / Time),              data = ChickWeight)   eta_squared(model, partial = TRUE) #> # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) #>  #> Group      | Parameter | Eta2 (partial) |       95% CI #> ------------------------------------------------------ #> Chick      |      Diet |           0.27 | [0.06, 1.00] #> Chick:Time |      Time |           0.87 | [0.85, 1.00] #> Chick:Time | Diet:Time |           0.22 | [0.11, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].  eta_squared(model, generalized = "Time") #> # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) #>  #> Group      | Parameter | Eta2 (generalized) |       95% CI #> ---------------------------------------------------------- #> Chick      |      Diet |               0.04 | [0.00, 1.00] #> Chick:Time |      Time |               0.74 | [0.71, 1.00] #> Chick:Time | Diet:Time |               0.03 | [0.00, 1.00] #>  #> - Observed variables: Time #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].

title: Support functions for model extensions
text: input data frame must columns: - Parameter (char) - name parameter , often, term. - Sum_Squares (num) - sum squares. - df (num) - degrees freedom associated Sum_Squares. - Mean_Square_residuals (num; optional) - present, calculated Sum_Squares / df. (column ignored.) exactly 1 row Parameter Residual. Optionally, one rows can (Intercept) value Parameter. example minimally valid data frame: Pass data frame .es_aov_simple(): output data frame columns: Parameter, effect size, (optionally) CI + CI_low + CI_high, following attributes: partial, generalized, ci, alternative, anova_type (NA NULL), approximate. can set anova_type attribute {1, 2, 3, NA} return output.
code: min_aov <- data.frame(   Parameter = c("(Intercept)", "A", "B", "Residuals"),   Sum_Squares = c(30, 40, 10, 100),   df = c(1, 1, 2, 50) ) .es_aov_simple(   min_aov,   type = "eta", partial = TRUE, generalized = FALSE,   include_intercept = FALSE,   ci = 0.95, alternative = "greater",   verbose = TRUE ) >   Parameter Eta2_partial   CI CI_low CI_high > 1         A        0.286 0.95   0.12       1 > 2         B        0.091 0.95   0.00       1

what: ANOVA Tables with Multiple Error Strata
title: Support functions for model extensions
text: (e.g., aovlist models.) input data frame must columns: Group (char) - strata Parameter (char) Sum_Squares (num) df (num) Mean_Square_residuals (num; optional) exactly 1 row per Group Parameter Residual. Optionally, one rows can (Intercept) value Parameter. example minimally valid data frame: Pass data frame .es_aov_strata(), along list predictors (including stratifying variables) DV_names argument: output data frame columns: Group, Parameter, effect size, (optionally) CI + CI_low + CI_high, following attributes: partial, generalized, ci, alternative, approximate. can set anova_type attribute {1, 2, 3, NA} return output.
code: min_aovlist <- data.frame(   Group = c("S", "S", "S:A", "S:A"),   Parameter = c("(Intercept)", "Residuals", "A", "Residuals"),   Sum_Squares = c(34, 21, 34, 400),   df = c(1, 12, 4, 30) ) .es_aov_strata(   min_aovlist, DV_names = c("S", "A"),   type = "omega", partial = TRUE, generalized = FALSE,   ci = 0.95, alternative = "greater",   verbose = TRUE,   include_intercept = TRUE ) >   Group   Parameter Omega2_partial   CI CI_low CI_high > 1     S (Intercept)          0.568 0.95   0.21       1 > 2   S:A           A         -0.042 0.95   0.00       1

Optionally, one rows can (Intercept) Parameter. example minimally valid data frame: Pass table .es_aov_table(): output data frame columns: Parameter, effect size, (optionally) CI + CI_low + CI_high, following attributes: partial, generalized, ci, alternative, approximate. can set anova_type attribute {1, 2, 3, NA} return output, optionally approximate attribute, return output.

title: Support functions for model extensions
text: Let’s fit simple linear model change class: now need new .anova_es.superMODEL function: … ’s ! new superMODEL class models fully supported!
code: mod <- lm(mpg ~ factor(cyl) + am, mtcars)  class(mod) <- "superMODEL" .anova_es.superMODEL <- function(model, ...) {   # Get ANOVA table   anov <- suppressWarnings(stats:::anova.lm(model))   anov <- as.data.frame(anov)      # Clean up   anov[["Parameter"]] <- rownames(anov)   colnames(anov)[2:1] <- c("Sum_Squares", "df")      # Pass   out <- .es_aov_simple(anov, ...)      # Set attribute   attr(out, "anova_type") <- 1      out } eta_squared(mod) > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) >  > Parameter   | Eta2 (partial) |       95% CI > ------------------------------------------- > factor(cyl) |           0.76 | [0.61, 1.00] > am          |           0.12 | [0.00, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. eta_squared(mod, partial = FALSE) > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) >  > Parameter   | Eta2 |       95% CI > --------------------------------- > factor(cyl) | 0.73 | [0.57, 1.00] > am          | 0.03 | [0.00, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. omega_squared(mod) > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) >  > Parameter   | Omega2 (partial) |       95% CI > --------------------------------------------- > factor(cyl) |             0.73 | [0.56, 1.00] > am          |             0.08 | [0.00, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. # Etc...

Thus information samples size (often degrees freedom) used reverse-engineer indices effect size test statistics. idea functions also power Effect Sizes Test Statistics shiny app. measures discussed , one way another, signal noise ratios, “noise” representing unaccounted variance outcome variable1. indices : Percent variance explained (\(\eta^2_p\), \(\omega^2_p\), \(\epsilon^2_p\)). Measure association (\(r\)). Measure difference (\(d\)).

title: Effect Size from Test Statistics
text: measures represent ratio \(Signal^2 / (Signal^2 + Noise^2)\), “noise” “signals” partial-ed (fixed random effects). popular indices \(\eta^2_p\) (Eta; equivalent \(R^2\)). conversion \(F\)- \(t\)-statistic based Friedman (1982). Let’s look example: Let’s compare \(\eta^2_p\) (pes column) obtained ones recovered F_to_eta2(): identical!2 (except fact F_to_eta2() also provides confidence intervals3 :) case able easily obtain effect size (thanks afex!), cases might easy, using estimates based test statistic offers good approximation. example:
code: library(afex)  data(md_12.1)  aov_fit <- aov_car(rt ~ angle * noise + Error(id / (angle * noise)),   data = md_12.1,   anova_table = list(correction = "none", es = "pes") ) aov_fit > Anova Table (Type 3 tests) >  > Response: rt >        Effect    df     MSE         F  pes p.value > 1       angle 2, 18 3560.00 40.72 *** .819   <.001 > 2       noise  1, 9 8460.00 33.77 *** .790   <.001 > 3 angle:noise 2, 18 1160.00 45.31 *** .834   <.001 > --- > Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '+' 0.1 ' ' 1 library(effectsize)  F_to_eta2(   f = c(40.72, 33.77, 45.31),   df = c(2, 1, 2),   df_error = c(18, 9, 18) ) > Eta2 (partial) |       95% CI > ----------------------------- > 0.82           | [0.66, 1.00] > 0.79           | [0.49, 1.00] > 0.83           | [0.69, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].

title: Effect Size from Test Statistics
text: can also use t_to_eta2() contrast analysis:
code: library(emmeans)  joint_tests(aov_fit, by = "noise") > noise = absent: >  model term df1 df2 F.ratio p.value >  angle        2   9   8.000  0.0096 >  > noise = present: >  model term df1 df2 F.ratio p.value >  angle        2   9  51.000  <.0001 F_to_eta2(   f = c(5, 79),   df = 2,   df_error = 29 ) > Eta2 (partial) |       95% CI > ----------------------------- > 0.26           | [0.04, 1.00] > 0.84           | [0.75, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. pairs(emmeans(aov_fit, ~angle)) >  contrast estimate   SE df t.ratio p.value >  X0 - X4      -108 17.4  9  -6.200  0.0004 >  X0 - X8      -168 20.6  9  -8.200  0.0001 >  X4 - X8       -60 18.4  9  -3.300  0.0244 >  > Results are averaged over the levels of: noise  > P value adjustment: tukey method for comparing a family of 3 estimates t_to_eta2(   t = c(-5.7, -8.9, -3.2),   df_error = 18 ) > Eta2 (partial) |       95% CI > ----------------------------- > 0.64           | [0.39, 1.00] > 0.81           | [0.66, 1.00] > 0.36           | [0.09, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].

title: Effect Size from Test Statistics
text: can also use t_to_eta2() slope Days (case gives result).
code: library(lmerTest)  fit_lmm <- lmer(Reaction ~ Days + (Days | Subject), sleepstudy)  anova(fit_lmm) > Type III Analysis of Variance Table with Satterthwaite's method >      Sum Sq Mean Sq NumDF DenDF F value  Pr(>F)     > Days  30031   30031     1    17    45.9 3.3e-06 *** > --- > Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 F_to_eta2(45.8, 1, 17) > Eta2 (partial) |       95% CI > ----------------------------- > 0.73           | [0.51, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. parameters::model_parameters(fit_lmm, effects = "fixed", ci_method = "satterthwaite") > # Fixed Effects >  > Parameter   | Coefficient |   SE |           95% CI | t(17.00) |      p > ----------------------------------------------------------------------- > (Intercept) |      251.41 | 6.82 | [237.01, 265.80] |    36.84 | < .001 > Days        |       10.47 | 1.55 | [  7.21,  13.73] |     6.77 | < .001 >  > Uncertainty intervals (equal-tailed) and p values (two-tailed) computed using a >   Wald t-distribution with Satterthwaite approximation. t_to_eta2(6.77, df_error = 17) > Eta2 (partial) |       95% CI > ----------------------------- > 0.73           | [0.51, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].

title: Effect Size from Test Statistics
text: Alongside \(\eta^2_p\) also less biased \(\omega_p^2\) (Omega) \(\epsilon^2_p\) (Epsilon; sometimes called \(\text{Adj. }\eta^2_p\), equivalent \(R^2_{adj}\); Albers Lakens (2018), Mordkoff (2019)).

title: Effect Size from Test Statistics
text: Similar \(\eta^2_p\), \(r\) signal noise ratio, fact equal \(\sqrt{\eta^2_p}\) (’s really partial \(r\)). often used instead \(\eta^2_p\) discussing strength association (suspect people use instead \(\eta^2_p\) gives bigger number, looks better).

title: Automated Interpretation of Indices of Effect Size
text: metrics used statistics (indices fit, model performance, parameter estimates) can abstract. long experience required intuitively feel meaning values. order facilitate understanding results facing, many scientists use (often implicitly) set rules thumb. rules thumb standardize validated subsequently published guidelines. Understandably , rules thumb just suggestions nothing universal . interpretation effect size measures always going relative discipline, specific data, aims analyst. important might considered small effect psychology might large field like public health. One famous interpretation grids proposed Cohen (1988) series widely used indices, correlation r (r = .20, small; r = .40, moderate r = .60, large) standardized difference (Cohen’s d). However, now clear evidence Cohen’s guidelines (later disavowed; Funder, 2019) much stringent particularly meaningful taken context (Funder Ozer 2019). led emergence literature discussing creating new sets rules thumb. Although everybody agrees fact effect size interpretation study justified rationale (depend context, field, literature, hypothesis, etc.), pre-baked rules can nevertheless useful give rough idea frame reference understand scientific results. package effectsize catalogs sets rules thumb variety indices flexible explicit fashion, helping understand report results scientific yet meaningful way. , readers keep mind thresholds, ubiquitous may , remain arbitrary. Thus, use discussed case--case basis depending field, hypotheses, prior results, , avoid crystallization, infamous \(p < .05\) criterion hypothesis testing. Moreover, authors suggest counter-intuitive idea large effects, especially context psychological research, likely “gross overestimate rarely found large sample replication” (Funder Ozer 2019). suggest smaller effect size worth taking seriously (can potentially consequential), well believable.

title: Effect Sizes for Simple Hypothesis Tests
text: two independent samples, rank-biserial correlation (\(r_{rb}\)) measure relative superiority - .e., larger values indicate higher probability randomly selected observation X larger randomly selected observation Y. value \((-1)\) indicates observations second group larger first, value \((+1)\) indicates observations first group larger second. common language effect size: one sample, \(r_{rb}\) measures symmetry around \(\mu\) (mu; null value), 0 indicating perfect symmetry, \((-1)\) indicates observations fall \(\mu\), \((+1)\) indicates observations fall \(\mu\). paired samples difference paired samples used:
code: A <- c(48, 48, 77, 86, 85, 85) B <- c(14, 34, 34, 77)  wilcox.test(A, B) # aka Mann–Whitney U test >  >   Wilcoxon rank sum test with continuity correction >  > data:  A and B > W = 22, p-value = 0.05 > alternative hypothesis: true location shift is not equal to 0 rank_biserial(A, B) > r (rank biserial) |       95% CI > -------------------------------- > 0.79              | [0.30, 0.95] cles(A, B, rank = TRUE) > Parameter       | Coefficient |       95% CI > -------------------------------------------- > Pr(superiority) |        0.85 | [0.49, 0.98] > Cohen's U3      |        0.93 | [0.49, 1.00] > Overlap         |        0.47 | [0.15, 1.00] x <- c(1.15, 0.88, 0.90, 0.74, 1.21, 1.36, 0.89)  wilcox.test(x, mu = 1) # aka Signed-Rank test >  >   Wilcoxon signed rank exact test >  > data:  x > V = 16, p-value = 0.8 > alternative hypothesis: true location is not equal to 1 rank_biserial(x, mu = 1) > r (rank biserial) |        95% CI > --------------------------------- > 0.14              | [-0.59, 0.75] >  > - Deviation from a difference of 1. x <- c(1.83, 0.50, 1.62, 2.48, 1.68, 1.88, 1.55, 3.06, 1.30) y <- c(0.878, 0.647, 0.598, 2.05, 1.06, 1.29, 1.06, 3.14, 1.29)  wilcox.test(x, y, paired = TRUE) # aka Signed-Rank test >  >   Wilcoxon signed rank exact test >  > data:  x and y > V = 40, p-value = 0.04 > alternative hypothesis: true location shift is not equal to 0 rank_biserial(x, y, paired = TRUE) > r (rank biserial) |       95% CI > -------------------------------- > 0.78              | [0.30, 0.94]

code: group_data <- list(   g1 = c(2.9, 3.0, 2.5, 2.6, 3.2), # normal subjects   g2 = c(3.8, 2.7, 4.0, 2.4), # with obstructive airway disease   g3 = c(2.8, 3.4, 3.7, 2.2, 2.0) # with asbestosis )  kruskal.test(group_data) >  >   Kruskal-Wallis rank sum test >  > data:  group_data > Kruskal-Wallis chi-squared = 0.8, df = 2, p-value = 0.7 rank_epsilon_squared(group_data) > Epsilon2 (rank) |       95% CI > ------------------------------ > 0.06            | [0.01, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].

title: Parameter and Model Standardization
text: Standardizing parameters (.e., coefficients) can allow comparison within models, variables studies. Moreover, returns coefficients expressed terms change variance (instance, coefficients expressed terms SD response variable), can allow usage effect size interpretation guidelines, Cohen’s (1988) famous rules thumb. However, standardizing model’s parameters automatically mindlessly done: research fields, particular variables types studies (e.g., replications), sometimes makes sense keep, use interpret original parameters, especially well known easily understood. Critically, parameters standardization trivial process. Different techniques exist, can lead drastically different results. Thus, critical standardization method explicitly documented detailed.

code: # Select portion of data containing the two levels of interest mtcars$am <- factor(mtcars$am, labels = c("Manual", "Automatic"))  m <- lm(mpg ~ am, data = mtcars) standardize_parameters(m) > # Standardization method: refit >  > Parameter   | Coefficient (std.) |         95% CI > ------------------------------------------------- > (Intercept) |              -0.49 | [-0.87, -0.11] > amAutomatic |               1.20 | [ 0.60,  1.80] cohens_d(mpg ~ am, data = mtcars) > Cohen's d |         95% CI > -------------------------- > -1.48     | [-2.27, -0.67] >  > - Estimated using pooled SD. coef(m)[2] / sigma(m) > amAutomatic  >         1.5 parameters::model_parameters(m) > Parameter      | Coefficient |   SE |         95% CI | t(30) |      p > --------------------------------------------------------------------- > (Intercept)    |       17.15 | 1.12 | [14.85, 19.44] | 15.25 | < .001 > am [Automatic] |        7.24 | 1.76 | [ 3.64, 10.85] |  4.11 | < .001 t_to_d(4.11, df_error = 30) > d    |       95% CI > ------------------- > 1.50 | [0.68, 2.30] m <- lm(mpg ~ am, data = mtcars)  standardize_parameters(m, method = "smart") > # Standardization method: smart >  > Parameter   | Coefficient (std.) |       95% CI > ----------------------------------------------- > (Intercept) |               0.00 | [0.00, 0.00] > amAutomatic |               1.17 | [0.59, 1.76] glass_delta(mpg ~ am, data = mtcars) > Glass' delta |         95% CI > ----------------------------- > -1.17        | [-1.93, -0.39]

code: data("hardlyworking", package = "effectsize")  head(hardlyworking) >   salary xtra_hours n_comps age seniority > 1  19745        4.2       1  32         3 > 2  11302        1.6       0  34         3 > 3  20636        1.2       3  33         5 > 4  23047        7.2       1  35         3 > 5  27342       11.3       0  33         4 > 6  25657        3.6       2  30         5 correlation::correlation(   hardlyworking,   select = "salary",   select2 = c("xtra_hours", "n_comps", "age", "seniority"),   partial = TRUE # get partial correlations ) > # Correlation Matrix (pearson-method) >  > Parameter1 | Parameter2 |    r |       95% CI | t(498) |         p > ------------------------------------------------------------------ > salary     | xtra_hours | 0.87 | [0.85, 0.89] |  39.79 | < .001*** > salary     |    n_comps | 0.71 | [0.66, 0.75] |  22.40 | < .001*** > salary     |        age | 0.09 | [0.01, 0.18] |   2.09 | 0.037*    > salary     |  seniority | 0.19 | [0.10, 0.27] |   4.30 | < .001*** >  > p-value adjustment method: Holm (1979) > Observations: 500 mod <- lm(salary ~ xtra_hours + n_comps + age + seniority,           data = hardlyworking)  standardize_parameters(mod) > # Standardization method: refit >  > Parameter   | Coefficient (std.) |        95% CI > ------------------------------------------------ > (Intercept) |          -4.52e-17 | [-0.03, 0.03] > xtra_hours  |               0.77 | [ 0.73, 0.81] > n_comps     |               0.39 | [ 0.36, 0.42] > age         |               0.04 | [ 0.00, 0.07] > seniority   |               0.08 | [ 0.04, 0.12] params <- parameters::model_parameters(mod)  t_to_r(params$t[-1], df_error = params$df_error[-1]) > r    |       95% CI > ------------------- > 0.87 | [0.85, 0.89] > 0.71 | [0.67, 0.74] > 0.09 | [0.01, 0.18] > 0.19 | [0.10, 0.27]

what: "refit": Re-fitting the model with standardized data
title: Parameter and Model Standardization
text: method based complete model re-fit standardized version data. Hence, method equal standardizing variables fitting model. “purest” accurate (Neter, Wasserman, Kutner 1989), also computationally costly long (especially heavy models Bayesian models, complex mixed models). method particularly recommended models include interactions transformations (e.g., exponentiation, log, polynomial spline terms). standardize_parameters also robust argument (default FALSE), enables robust standardization data, .e., based median MAD instead mean SD: Note since age_g factor, numerically standardized, standardized parameter still directly comparable numeric variables. address , can set two_sd = TRUE, thereby scaling parameters 2 SDs (MADs) predictors (Gelman 2008). effectsize also comes helper function returns re-fit model, without summarizing , can used original model :
code: standardize_parameters(mod, method = "refit") > # Standardization method: refit >  > Parameter    | Coefficient (std.) |        95% CI > ------------------------------------------------- > (Intercept)  |              -0.05 | [-0.11, 0.02] > xtra_hours   |               0.77 | [ 0.73, 0.81] > n_comps      |               0.39 | [ 0.36, 0.43] > age_g(30,35] |               0.06 | [-0.01, 0.14] > age_g(35,45] |               0.10 | [-0.04, 0.23] > seniority    |               0.08 | [ 0.04, 0.12] standardize_parameters(mod, method = "refit", robust = TRUE) > # Standardization method: refit >  > Parameter    | Coefficient (std.) |         95% CI > -------------------------------------------------- > (Intercept)  |              -0.20 | [-0.27, -0.13] > xtra_hours   |               0.65 | [ 0.62,  0.68] > n_comps      |               0.82 | [ 0.74,  0.89] > age_g(30,35] |               0.07 | [-0.01,  0.16] > age_g(35,45] |               0.11 | [-0.05,  0.27] > seniority    |               0.12 | [ 0.07,  0.18] >  > - Scaled by one MAD from the median. standardize_parameters(mod, method = "refit", two_sd = TRUE) > # Standardization method: refit >  > Parameter    | Coefficient (std.) |        95% CI > ------------------------------------------------- > (Intercept)  |              -0.05 | [-0.11, 0.02] > xtra_hours   |               1.54 | [ 1.46, 1.61] > n_comps      |               0.78 | [ 0.72, 0.85] > age_g(30,35] |               0.06 | [-0.01, 0.14] > age_g(35,45] |               0.10 | [-0.04, 0.23] > seniority    |               0.16 | [ 0.09, 0.24] >  > - Scaled by two SDs from the mean. mod_z <- standardize(mod, two_sd = FALSE, robust = FALSE) mod_z >  > Call: > lm(formula = salary ~ xtra_hours + n_comps + age_g + seniority,  >     data = data_std) >  > Coefficients: >  (Intercept)    xtra_hours       n_comps  age_g(30,35]  age_g(35,45]   >      -0.0458        0.7692        0.3921        0.0635        0.0962   >    seniority   >       0.0821 parameters::model_parameters(mod_z) > Parameter     | Coefficient |   SE |        95% CI | t(494) |      p > -------------------------------------------------------------------- > (Intercept)   |       -0.05 | 0.03 | [-0.11, 0.02] |  -1.47 | 0.142  > xtra hours    |        0.77 | 0.02 | [ 0.73, 0.81] |  39.76 | < .001 > n comps       |        0.39 | 0.02 | [ 0.36, 0.43] |  22.46 | < .001 > age g [31-35] |        0.06 | 0.04 | [-0.01, 0.14] |   1.63 | 0.103  > age g [36-45] |        0.10 | 0.07 | [-0.04, 0.23] |   1.39 | 0.164  > seniority     |        0.08 | 0.02 | [ 0.04, 0.12] |   4.34 | < .001

previous_headings: Introduction > Standardizing Parameters of Linear Models
title: Parameter and Model Standardization
text: Linear mixed models (LMM/HLM/MLM) offer additional conundrum standardization - one even calculate SDs various predictors? response - deviations within group? perhaps ? solution: standardize according level predictor (Hoffman 2015, 342)! Level 1 parameters standardized according variance within groups, level 2 parameters standardized according variance groups. resulting standardized coefficient also called pseudo-standardized coefficients.[^Note like method "basic", based model matrix.]
code: m <- lme4::lmer(Reaction ~ Days + (Days|Subject), data = lme4::sleepstudy)  standardize_parameters(m, method = "pseudo", ci_method = "satterthwaite") > # Standardization method: pseudo >  > Parameter   | Coefficient (std.) |       95% CI > ----------------------------------------------- > (Intercept) |               0.00 | [0.00, 0.00] > Days        |               0.68 | [0.47, 0.89] # compare to: standardize_parameters(m, method = "basic", ci_method = "satterthwaite") > # Standardization method: basic >  > Parameter   | Coefficient (std.) |       95% CI > ----------------------------------------------- > (Intercept) |               0.00 | [0.00, 0.00] > Days        |               0.54 | [0.37, 0.70]

what: Standardizing Parameters In Generalized Linear Models
title: Parameter and Model Standardization
text: Unlike linear (/mixed) models, generalized linear (/mixed) models (GLMs) less need standardization. ? many GLMs estimated coefficients measures effect size, odds-ratios () logistic regression, incidence rate ratios (IRR) Poisson regressions. model outcome arbitrary scale - , meaning rates probabilities changed arbitrary linear transformations. still, standardization sometimes needed, predictors. Luckily, standardize_parameters() (standardize()) smart enough know GLMs passed standardize according predictors: can converted (exp()) discussed “change Odds function change one SD x”. can directly ask coefficients exponentiated:
code: mod_b <- glm(am ~ mpg + factor(cyl),              data = mtcars,              family = binomial())  standardize_parameters(mod_b, method = "refit", two_sd = TRUE) > # Standardization method: refit >  > Parameter                      | Coefficient (std.) |         95% CI > -------------------------------------------------------------------- > (Intercept)                    |              -0.91 | [-3.32,  1.33] > mpg                            |               4.46 | [ 0.30, 10.54] > factor(cyl)-0.0524939042876197 |               0.73 | [-2.04,  3.66] > factor(cyl)0.507441074780324   |               0.70 | [-3.13,  4.78] >  > - Scaled by two SDs from the mean. > - Response is unstandardized. # standardize_parameters(mod_b, method = "posthoc", two_sd = TRUE) # standardize_parameters(mod_b, method = "basic") std <- standardize_parameters(mod_b, method = "refit", two_sd = TRUE) exp(std$Std_Coefficient) > [1]  0.4 86.4  2.1  2.0 standardize_parameters(mod_b, method = "refit", two_sd = TRUE, exponentiate = TRUE) > # Standardization method: refit >  > Parameter                      | Odds Ratio (std.) |           95% CI > --------------------------------------------------------------------- > (Intercept)                    |              0.40 | [0.04,     3.76] > mpg                            |             86.40 | [1.36, 37955.41] > factor(cyl)-0.0524939042876197 |              2.08 | [0.13,    39.04] > factor(cyl)0.507441074780324   |              2.02 | [0.04,   119.12] >  > - Scaled by two SDs from the mean. > - Response is unstandardized.

title: Parameter and Model Standardization
text: Cohen’s \(f\) (ANOVA fame) can used measure effect size context sequential multiple regression (.e., nested models). , comparing two models, can examine ratio increase \(R^2\) unexplained variance: \[ f^{2}={R_{AB}^{2}-R_{}^{2} \1-R_{AB}^{2}} \]
code: m1 <- lm(salary ~ xtra_hours, data = hardlyworking) m2 <- lm(salary ~ xtra_hours + n_comps + seniority, data = hardlyworking)  cohens_f_squared(m1, model2 = m2) > Cohen's f2 (partial) |      95% CI | R2_delta > --------------------------------------------- > 1.19                 | [0.99, Inf] |     0.17 >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [Inf].

text: data frame effect size(s) 0-1 (Eta2_partial, Epsilon2_partial, Omega2_partial, Cohens_f_partial Cohens_f2_partial), CIs (CI_low CI_high). (Note \(\omega_p^2\) \(\epsilon_p^2\) possible compute negative number; even though make practical sense, recommended report negative number 0).

title:
Convert test statistics (F, t) to indices of partial variance explained
(partial Eta / Omega / Epsilon squared and Cohen's f) — F_to_eta2
text: functions use following formulae:  $$\eta_p^2 = \frac{F \times df_{num}}{F \times df_{num} + df_{den}}$$  $$\epsilon_p^2 = \frac{(F - 1) \times df_{num}}{F \times df_{num} + df_{den}}$$  $$\omega_p^2 = \frac{(F - 1) \times df_{num}}{F \times df_{num} + df_{den} + 1}$$  $$f_p = \sqrt{\frac{\eta_p^2}{1-\eta_p^2}}$$  t, conversion based equality \(t^2 = F\) \(df_{num}=1\).

Note confidence interval including 0 indicate null (effect) true. code: mod <- aov(mpg ~ factor(cyl) * factor(am), mtcars) anova(mod) #> Analysis of Variance Table #>  #> Response: mpg #>                        Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value    Pr(>F)     #> factor(cyl)             2 824.78  412.39 44.8517 3.725e-09 *** #> factor(am)              1  36.77   36.77  3.9988   0.05608 .   #> factor(cyl):factor(am)  2  25.44   12.72  1.3832   0.26861     #> Residuals              26 239.06    9.19                       #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 (etas <- F_to_eta2(   f = c(44.85, 3.99, 1.38),   df = c(2, 1, 2),   df_error = 26 )) #> Eta2 (partial) |       95% CI #> ----------------------------- #> 0.78           | [0.63, 1.00] #> 0.13           | [0.00, 1.00] #> 0.10           | [0.00, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].  if (require(see)) plot(etas) #> Loading required package: see   # Compare to: eta_squared(mod) #> # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) #>  #> Parameter              | Eta2 (partial) |       95% CI #> ------------------------------------------------------ #> factor(cyl)            |           0.78 | [0.63, 1.00] #> factor(am)             |           0.13 | [0.00, 1.00] #> factor(cyl):factor(am) |           0.10 | [0.00, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].  # \donttest{ fit <- lmerTest::lmer(extra ~ group + (1 | ID), sleep) # anova(fit) # #> Type III Analysis of Variance Table with Satterthwaite's method # #>       Sum Sq Mean Sq NumDF DenDF F value   Pr(>F) # #> group 12.482  12.482     1     9  16.501 0.002833 ** # #> --- # #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1  F_to_eta2(16.501, 1, 9) #> Eta2 (partial) |       95% CI #> ----------------------------- #> 0.65           | [0.25, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. F_to_omega2(16.501, 1, 9) #> Omega2 (partial) |       95% CI #> ------------------------------- #> 0.58             | [0.17, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. F_to_epsilon2(16.501, 1, 9) #> Epsilon2 (partial) |       95% CI #> --------------------------------- #> 0.61               | [0.20, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. F_to_f(16.501, 1, 9) #> Cohen's f (partial) |      95% CI #> --------------------------------- #> 1.35                | [0.57, Inf] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [Inf]. # }  #' @examplesIf require(lmerTest) # \donttest{ ## Use with emmeans based contrasts ## -------------------------------- warp.lm <- lm(breaks ~ wool * tension, data = warpbreaks)  jt <- emmeans::joint_tests(warp.lm, by = "wool") F_to_eta2(jt$F.ratio, jt$df1, jt$df2) #> Eta2 (partial) |       95% CI #> ----------------------------- #> 0.30           | [0.12, 1.00] #> 0.09           | [0.00, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. # }

title: Conversion Chi-Squared to Phi or Cramer's V — chisq_to_phi

title: Effect size for differences — cohens_d
text: Compute effect size indices standardized differences: Cohen's d, Hedges' g Glass’s delta (\(\Delta\)). (function returns population estimate.)  Cohen's d Hedges' g estimated standardized difference means two populations. Hedges' g provides bias correction (using exact method) Cohen's d small sample sizes. sample sizes > 20, results statistics roughly equivalent. Glass’s delta appropriate standard deviations significantly different populations, uses second group's standard deviation.

Deviation from a difference of 3. hedges_g(wt ~ 1, data = mtcars, mu = 3) #> Hedges' g |        95% CI #> ------------------------- #> 0.22      | [-0.13, 0.57] #>  #> - Deviation from a difference of 3.   # Paired Samples ----------  data(sleep)  cohens_d(Pair(extra[group == 1], extra[group == 2]) ~ 1, data = sleep) #> Cohen's d |         95% CI #> -------------------------- #> -1.28     | [-2.23, -0.44]  # same as: # cohens_d(sleep$extra[sleep$group == 1], sleep$extra[sleep$group == 2], paired = TRUE)  # More options: cohens_d(Pair(extra[group == 1], extra[group == 2]) ~ 1, data = sleep, mu = -1) #> Cohen's d |        95% CI #> ------------------------- #> -0.47     | [-1.18, 0.21] #>  #> - Deviation from a difference of -1. hedges_g(Pair(extra[group == 1], extra[group == 2]) ~ 1, data = sleep) #> Hedges' g |         95% CI #> -------------------------- #> -1.17     | [-2.04, -0.40]   # Interpretation ----------------------- interpret_cohens_d(-1.48, rules = "cohen1988") #> [1] "large" #> (Rules: cohen1988) #>  interpret_hedges_g(-1.48, rules = "sawilowsky2009") #> [1] "very large" #> (Rules: sawilowsky2009) #>  interpret_glass_delta(-1.48, rules = "gignac2016") #> [1] "large" #> (Rules: gignac2016) #>  # Or: interpret(d, rules = "sawilowsky2009") #> Cohen's d |         95% CI | Interpretation #> ------------------------------------------- #> -1.48     | [-2.27, -0.67] |     very large #>  #> - title: Convert Standardized Mean Difference to Common Language Effect Sizes — d_to_cles
text: function use following formulae Cohen's d: $$Pr(superiority) = \Phi(d/\sqrt{2})$$  $$Cohen's U_3 = \Phi(d)$$  $$Overlap = 2 \times \Phi(-|d|/2)$$  following rank-biserial correlation: $$Pr(superiority) = (r_{rb} + 1)/2$$

title: Convert between d, r and Odds ratio — d_to_r

title: Effect Size — effectsize.BFBayesFactor
code: ## Hypothesis Testing ## ------------------ contingency_table <- as.table(rbind(c(762, 327, 468), c(484, 239, 477), c(484, 239, 477))) Xsq <- chisq.test(contingency_table) effectsize(Xsq) #> Cramer's V |       95% CI #> ------------------------- #> 0.07       | [0.05, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. effectsize(Xsq, type = "phi") #> Phi  |       95% CI #> ------------------- #> 0.10 | [0.07, 1.41] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.41~].  Tt <- t.test(1:10, y = c(7:20), alternative = "less") effectsize(Tt) #> Cohen's d |        95% CI #> ------------------------- #> -2.19     | [-Inf, -1.32] #>  #> - Estimated using un-pooled SD. #> - One-sided CIs: lower bound fixed at [-Inf].  Aov <- oneway.test(extra ~ group, data = sleep, var.equal = TRUE) effectsize(Aov) #> Eta2 |       95% CI #> ------------------- #> 0.16 | [0.00, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. effectsize(Aov, type = "omega") #> Omega2 |       95% CI #> --------------------- #> 0.11   | [0.00, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].  Wt <- wilcox.test(1:10, 7:20, mu = -3, alternative = "less") #> Warning: cannot compute exact p-value with ties effectsize(Wt) #> r (rank biserial) |         95% CI #> ---------------------------------- #> -0.65             | [-1.00, -0.36] #>  #> - Deviation from a difference of -3. #> - One-sided CIs: lower bound fixed at [-1.00]. effectsize(Wt, type = "cles") #> Parameter       | Coefficient |       95% CI #> -------------------------------------------- #> Pr(superiority) |        0.18 | [0.00, 0.32] #> Cohen's U3      |        0.00 | [0.00, 0.13] #> Overlap         |        0.85 | [0.00, 1.11] #>  #> -  #> - Non-parametric CLES #> - cyan  ## Bayesian Hypothesis Testing ## --------------------------- # \donttest{ if (require(BayesFactor)) {   bf_prop <- proportionBF(3, 7, p = 0.3)   effectsize(bf_prop)    bf_corr <- correlationBF(attitude$rating, attitude$complaints)   effectsize(bf_corr)    data(raceDolls)   bf_xtab <- contingencyTableBF(raceDolls, sampleType = "poisson", fixedMargin = "cols")   effectsize(bf_xtab)   effectsize(bf_xtab, type = "oddsratio")    bf_ttest <- ttestBF(sleep$extra[sleep$group==1],                       sleep$extra[sleep$group==2],                       paired = TRUE, mu = -1)   effectsize(bf_ttest) } #> Loading required package: BayesFactor #> Loading required package: coda #> ************ #> Welcome to BayesFactor 0.9.12-4.3. If you have questions, please contact Richard Morey (richarddmorey@gmail.com). #>  #> Type BFManual() to open the manual. #> ************ #> Cohen's d |        95% CI #> ------------------------- #> -0.32     | [-1.00, 0.32] #>  #> - Deviation from a difference of -1. # }  ## Models and Anova Tables ## ----------------------- fit <- lm(mpg ~ factor(cyl) * wt + hp, data = mtcars) effectsize(fit) #> # Standardization method: refit #>  #> Parameter                        | Coefficient (std.) |         95% CI #> ---------------------------------------------------------------------- #> (Intercept)                      |           1.14e-03 | [-0.53,  0.53] #> factor(cyl)-0.104987808575239    |              -0.20 | [-0.79,  0.38] #> factor(cyl)1.01488214956065      |              -0.32 | [-1.06,  0.42] #> wt                               |              -0.90 | [-1.33, -0.46] #> hp                               |              -0.25 | [-0.52,  0.01] #> factor(cyl)-0.104987808575239:wt |               0.37 | [-0.63,  1.36] #> factor(cyl)1.01488214956065:wt   |               0.54 | [ 0.03,  1.06]  anova_table <- anova(fit) effectsize(anova_table) #> # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) #>  #> Parameter      | Eta2 (partial) |       95% CI #> ---------------------------------------------- #> factor(cyl)    |           0.86 | [0.76, 1.00] #> wt             |           0.47 | [0.22, 1.00] #> hp             |           0.14 | [0.00, 1.00] #> factor(cyl):wt |           0.16 | [0.00, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. effectsize(anova_table, type = "epsilon") #> # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) #>  #> Parameter      | Epsilon2 (partial) |       95% CI #> -------------------------------------------------- #> factor(cyl)    |               0.85 | [0.74, 1.00] #> wt             |               0.44 | [0.20, 1.00] #> hp             |               0.11 | [0.00, 1.00] #> factor(cyl):wt |               0.09 | [0.00, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].

text: Functions compute effect size measures ANOVAs, Eta- (\(\eta\)), Omega- (\(\omega\)) Epsilon- (\(\epsilon\)) squared, Cohen's f (partialled versions) ANOVA tables. indices represent estimate much variance response variables accounted explanatory variable(s).  passing models, effect sizes computed using sums squares obtained anova(model) might always appropriate. See details.

title: Effect size for ANOVA — eta_squared
code: eta_squared(   model,   partial = TRUE,   generalized = FALSE,   ci = 0.95,   alternative = "greater",   verbose = TRUE,   ... )  omega_squared(   model,   partial = TRUE,   ci = 0.95,   alternative = "greater",   verbose = TRUE,   ... )  epsilon_squared(   model,   partial = TRUE,   ci = 0.95,   alternative = "greater",   verbose = TRUE,   ... )  cohens_f(   model,   partial = TRUE,   ci = 0.95,   alternative = "greater",   squared = FALSE,   verbose = TRUE,   model2 = NULL,   ... )  cohens_f_squared(   model,   partial = TRUE,   ci = 0.95,   alternative = "greater",   squared = TRUE,   verbose = TRUE,   model2 = NULL,   ... )  eta_squared_posterior(   model,   partial = TRUE,   generalized = FALSE,   ss_function = stats::anova,   draws = 500,   verbose = TRUE,   ... )

title: Effect size for ANOVA — eta_squared
text: model model, ANOVA object, result parameters::model_parameters. partial TRUE, return partial indices. generalized TRUE, returns generalized Eta Squared, assuming variables manipulated. Can also character vector observed (non-manipulated) variables, case generalized Eta Squared calculated taking observed variables account. afex_aov model, generalized = TRUE, observed variables extracted automatically fitted model, provided . ci Confidence Interval (CI) level alternative character string specifying alternative hypothesis; Controls type CI returned: "greater" (default) "less" (one-sided CI), "two.sided" (default, two-sided CI). Partial matching allowed (e.g., "g", "l", "two"...). See One-Sided CIs effectsize_CIs. verbose Toggle warnings messages . ... Arguments passed methods. Can include_intercept = TRUE include effect size intercept. Bayesian models, arguments passed ss_function. squared Return Cohen's f Cohen's f-squared? model2 Optional second model Cohen's f (/squared). specified, returns effect size R-squared-change two models. ss_function Bayesian models, function used extract sum--squares. Uses anova() default, can also car::Anova() simple linear models. draws Bayesian models, integer indicating number draws posterior predictive distribution return. Larger numbers take longer run, provide estimates stable.

title: Effect size for ANOVA — eta_squared
code: data(mtcars) mtcars$am_f <- factor(mtcars$am) mtcars$cyl_f <- factor(mtcars$cyl)  model <- aov(mpg ~ am_f * cyl_f, data = mtcars)  (eta2 <- eta_squared(model)) #> # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) #>  #> Parameter  | Eta2 (partial) |       95% CI #> ------------------------------------------ #> am_f       |           0.63 | [0.42, 1.00] #> cyl_f      |           0.66 | [0.45, 1.00] #> am_f:cyl_f |           0.10 | [0.00, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].  # More types: eta_squared(model, partial = FALSE) #> # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) #>  #> Parameter  | Eta2 |       95% CI #> -------------------------------- #> am_f       | 0.36 | [0.13, 1.00] #> cyl_f      | 0.41 | [0.14, 1.00] #> am_f:cyl_f | 0.02 | [0.00, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. eta_squared(model, generalized = "cyl_f") #> # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) #>  #> Parameter  | Eta2 (generalized) |       95% CI #> ---------------------------------------------- #> am_f       |               0.36 | [0.13, 1.00] #> cyl_f      |               0.63 | [0.42, 1.00] #> am_f:cyl_f |               0.04 | [0.00, 1.00] #>  #> - Observed variables: cyl_f #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. omega_squared(model) #> # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) #>  #> Parameter  | Omega2 (partial) |       95% CI #> -------------------------------------------- #> am_f       |             0.57 | [0.35, 1.00] #> cyl_f      |             0.60 | [0.37, 1.00] #> am_f:cyl_f |             0.02 | [0.00, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. epsilon_squared(model) #> # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) #>  #> Parameter  | Epsilon2 (partial) |       95% CI #> ---------------------------------------------- #> am_f       |               0.61 | [0.40, 1.00] #> cyl_f      |               0.63 | [0.41, 1.00] #> am_f:cyl_f |               0.03 | [0.00, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. cohens_f(model) #> # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) #>  #> Parameter  | Cohen's f (partial) |      95% CI #> ---------------------------------------------- #> am_f       |                1.30 | [0.86, Inf] #> cyl_f      |                1.38 | [0.90, Inf] #> am_f:cyl_f |                0.33 | [0.00, Inf] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [Inf].  if (require(see)) plot(eta2)   model0 <- aov(mpg ~ am_f + cyl_f, data = mtcars) # no interaction cohens_f_squared(model0, model2 = model) #> Cohen's f2 (partial) |      95% CI | R2_delta #> --------------------------------------------- #> 0.11                 | [0.00, Inf] |     0.02 #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [Inf].  ## Interpretation of effect sizes ## ------------------------------  interpret_omega_squared(0.10, rules = "field2013") #> [1] "medium" #> (Rules: field2013) #>  interpret_eta_squared(0.10, rules = "cohen1992") #> [1] "small" #> (Rules: cohen1992) #>  interpret_epsilon_squared(0.10, rules = "cohen1992") #> [1] "small" #> (Rules: cohen1992) #>   interpret(eta2, rules = "cohen1992") #> # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) #>  #> Parameter  | Eta2 (partial) |       95% CI | Interpretation #> ----------------------------------------------------------- #> am_f       |           0.63 | [0.42, 1.00] |          large #> cyl_f      |           0.66 | [0.45, 1.00] |          large #> am_f:cyl_f |           0.10 | [0.00, 1.00] |          small #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. #> - Interpretation rule: cohen1992   # Recommended: Type-2 or -3 effect sizes + effects coding # ------------------------------------------------------- contrasts(mtcars$am_f) <- contr.sum contrasts(mtcars$cyl_f) <- contr.sum  model <- aov(mpg ~ am_f * cyl_f, data = mtcars) model_anova <- car::Anova(model, type = 3)  eta_squared(model_anova) #> Type 3 ANOVAs only give sensible and informative results when covariates are #>   mean-centered and factors are coded with orthogonal contrasts (such as those #>   produced by 'contr.sum', 'contr.poly', or 'contr.helmert', but *not* by the #>   default 'contr.treatment'). #> # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) #>  #> Parameter  | Eta2 (partial) |       95% CI #> ------------------------------------------ #> am_f       |           0.11 | [0.00, 1.00] #> cyl_f      |           0.63 | [0.42, 1.00] #> am_f:cyl_f |           0.10 | [0.00, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].  # afex takes care of both type-3 effects and effects coding: data(obk.long, package = "afex") model <- afex::aov_car(value ~ treatment * gender + Error(id / (phase)),                        data = obk.long, observed = "gender") #> Warning: More than one observation per cell, aggregating the data using mean (i.e, fun_aggregate = mean)! #> Contrasts set to contr.sum for the following variables: treatment, gender eta_squared(model) #> # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) #>  #> Parameter              | Eta2 (partial) |       95% CI #> ------------------------------------------------------ #> treatment              |           0.44 | [0.00, 1.00] #> gender                 |           0.27 | [0.00, 1.00] #> treatment:gender       |           0.36 | [0.00, 1.00] #> phase                  |           0.62 | [0.35, 1.00] #> treatment:phase        |           0.49 | [0.14, 1.00] #> gender:phase           |           0.03 | [0.00, 1.00] #> treatment:gender:phase |           0.11 | [0.00, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. epsilon_squared(model) #> # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) #>  #> Parameter              | Epsilon2 (partial) |       95% CI #> ---------------------------------------------------------- #> treatment              |               0.33 | [0.00, 1.00] #> gender                 |               0.19 | [0.00, 1.00] #> treatment:gender       |               0.24 | [0.00, 1.00] #> phase                  |               0.58 | [0.30, 1.00] #> treatment:phase        |               0.39 | [0.02, 1.00] #> gender:phase           |              -0.07 | [0.00, 1.00] #> treatment:gender:phase |              -0.06 | [0.00, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. omega_squared(model) #> # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) #>  #> Parameter              | Omega2 (partial) |       95% CI #> -------------------------------------------------------- #> treatment              |             0.31 | [0.00, 1.00] #> gender                 |             0.18 | [0.00, 1.00] #> treatment:gender       |             0.22 | [0.00, 1.00] #> phase                  |             0.26 | [0.00, 1.00] #> treatment:phase        |             0.15 | [0.00, 1.00] #> gender:phase           |            -0.02 | [0.00, 1.00] #> treatment:gender:phase |            -0.02 | [0.00, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. eta_squared(model, generalized = TRUE) # observed vars are pulled from the afex model. #> # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) #>  #> Parameter              | Eta2 (generalized) |       95% CI #> ---------------------------------------------------------- #> treatment              |               0.25 | [0.00, 1.00] #> gender                 |               0.16 | [0.00, 1.00] #> treatment:gender       |               0.24 | [0.00, 1.00] #> phase                  |               0.20 | [0.00, 1.00] #> treatment:phase        |               0.13 | [0.00, 1.00] #> gender:phase           |           4.25e-03 | [0.00, 1.00] #> treatment:gender:phase |               0.02 | [0.00, 1.00] #>  #> - Observed variables: gender #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].  ## Approx. effect sizes for mixed models ## ------------------------------------- model <- lme4::lmer(mpg ~ am_f * cyl_f + (1 | vs), data = mtcars) #> boundary (singular) fit: see help('isSingular') omega_squared(model) #> # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) #>  #> Parameter  | Omega2 (partial) |       95% CI #> -------------------------------------------- #> am_f       |             0.07 | [0.00, 1.00] #> cyl_f      |             0.60 | [0.36, 1.00] #> am_f:cyl_f |             0.03 | [0.00, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].  ## Bayesian Models (PPD) ## --------------------- if (FALSE) { fit_bayes <- rstanarm::stan_glm(   mpg ~ factor(cyl) * wt + qsec,   data = mtcars, family = gaussian(),   refresh = 0 )  es <- eta_squared_posterior(fit_bayes, verbose = FALSE,                             ss_function = car::Anova, type = 3) bayestestR::describe_posterior(es, test = NULL)   # compare to: fit_freq <- lm(mpg ~ factor(cyl) * wt + qsec,                data = mtcars) aov_table <- car::Anova(fit_freq, type = 3) eta_squared(aov_table) }
