title: Generic function for interpretation — interpret
code: rules_grid <- rules(c(0.01, 0.05), c("very significant", "significant", "not significant")) interpret(0.001, rules_grid) #> [1] "very significant" #> (Rules: Custom rules) #>  interpret(0.021, rules_grid) #> [1] "significant" #> (Rules: Custom rules) #>  interpret(0.08, rules_grid) #> [1] "not significant" #> (Rules: Custom rules) #>  interpret(c(0.01, 0.005, 0.08), rules_grid) #> [1] "very significant" "very significant" "not significant"  #> (Rules: Custom rules) #>   interpret(c(0.35, 0.15), c("small" = 0.2, "large" = 0.4), name = "Cohen's Rules") #> [1] "large" "small" #> (Rules: Cohen's Rules) #>  interpret(c(0.35, 0.15), rules(c(0.2, 0.4), c("small", "medium", "large"))) #> [1] "medium" "small"  #> (Rules: Custom rules) #>   # ---------- d <- cohens_d(mpg ~ am, data = mtcars) interpret(d, rules = "cohen1988") #> Cohen's d |         95% CI | Interpretation #> ------------------------------------------- #> -1.48     | [-2.27, -0.67] |          large #>  #> - Estimated using pooled SD. #> - Interpretation rule: cohen1988  d <- glass_delta(mpg ~ am, data = mtcars) interpret(d, rules = "gignac2016") #> Glass' delta |         95% CI | Interpretation #> ---------------------------------------------- #> -1.17        | [-1.93, -0.39] |          large #>  #> - Interpretation rule: gignac2016  interpret(d, rules = rules(1, c("tiny", "yeah okay"))) #> Glass' delta |         95% CI | Interpretation #> ---------------------------------------------- #> -1.17        | [-1.93, -0.39] |      yeah okay #>  #> - Interpretation rule: Custom rules  m <- lm(formula = wt ~ am * cyl, data = mtcars) eta2 <- eta_squared(m) interpret(eta2, rules = "field2013") #> # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) #>  #> Parameter | Eta2 (partial) |       95% CI | Interpretation #> ---------------------------------------------------------- #> am        |           0.63 | [0.44, 1.00] |          large #> cyl       |           0.47 | [0.24, 1.00] |          large #> am:cyl    |       2.26e-03 | [0.00, 1.00] |     very small #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. #> - Interpretation rule: field2013  X <- chisq.test(mtcars$am, mtcars$cyl == 8) interpret(oddsratio(X), rules = "chen2010") #> Odds ratio |       95% CI | Interpretation #> ------------------------------------------ #> 0.11       | [0.02, 0.62] |          large #>  #> - Interpretation rule: chen2010 interpret(cramers_v(X), "lovakov2021") #> Cramer's V |       95% CI | Interpretation #> ------------------------------------------ #> 0.47       | [0.18, 1.00] |          large #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. #> - Interpretation rule: lovakov2021

title: Interpret of indices of CFA / SEM goodness of fit — interpret_gfi
text: Chisq: model Chi-squared assesses overall fit discrepancy sample fitted covariance matrices. p-value > .05 (.e., hypothesis perfect fit rejected). However, quite sensitive sample size. GFI/AGFI: (Adjusted) Goodness Fit proportion variance accounted estimated population covariance. Analogous R2. GFI AGFI > .95 > .90, respectively. NFI/NNFI/TLI: (Non) Normed Fit Index. NFI 0.95, indicates model interest improves fit 95\ NNFI (also called Tucker Lewis index; TLI) preferable smaller samples. > .90 (Byrne, 1994) > .95 (Schumacker & Lomax, 2004). CFI: Comparative Fit Index revised form NFI. sensitive sample size (Fan, Thompson, & Wang, 1999). Compares fit target model fit independent, null, model. > .90. RMSEA: Root Mean Square Error Approximation parsimony-adjusted index. Values closer 0 represent good fit. < .08 < .05. p-value printed tests hypothesis RMSEA less equal .05 (cutoff sometimes used good fit), thus significant. RMR/SRMR: (Standardized) Root Mean Square Residual represents square-root difference residuals sample covariance matrix hypothesized model. RMR can sometimes hard interpret, better use SRMR. < .08. RFI: Relative Fit Index, also known RHO1, guaranteed vary 0 1. However, RFI close 1 indicates good fit. IFI: Incremental Fit Index (IFI) adjusts Normed Fit Index (NFI) sample size degrees freedom (Bollen's, 1989). 0.90 good fit, index can exceed 1. PNFI: Parsimony-Adjusted Measures Index. commonly agreed-upon cutoff value acceptable model index. > 0.50. See documentation fitmeasures().

code: p0 <- 0.4 p1 <- 0.7  (OR <- probs_to_odds(p1) / probs_to_odds(p0)) #> [1] 3.5 (RR <- p1 / p0) #> [1] 1.75  riskratio_to_oddsratio(RR, p0 = p0) #> [1] 3.5 oddsratio_to_riskratio(OR, p0 = p0) #> [1] 1.75  m <- glm(am ~ factor(cyl), data = mtcars,          family = binomial()) oddsratio_to_riskratio(m) #> Warning: 'p0' not provided.RR is relative to the intercept (p0 = 0.73) - make sure your intercept is meaningful. #> Warning: CIs are back-transformed from the logit scale. #> Parameter   | Risk Ratio |       95% CI #> --------------------------------------- #> (Intercept) |       0.73 |              #> cyl [6]     |       0.59 | [0.11, 1.16] #> cyl [8]     |       0.20 | [0.02, 0.70] #>  #> Uncertainty intervals (profile-likelihood) and p values (two-tailed) computed #>   using a Wald z-distribution approximation.

code: M <-   matrix(c(150, 100, 165,            130, 50, 65,            35, 10, 2,            55, 40, 25), nrow = 4,          dimnames = list(            Music = c("Pop", "Rock", "Jazz", "Classic"),            Study = c("Psych", "Econ", "Law"))) M #>          Study #> Music     Psych Econ Law #>   Pop       150   50   2 #>   Rock      100   65  55 #>   Jazz      165   35  40 #>   Classic   130   10  25  # Note that Phi is not bound to [0-1], but instead # the upper bound for phi is sqrt(min(nrow, ncol) - 1) phi(M) #> Phi  |       95% CI #> ------------------- #> 0.34 | [0.27, 1.41] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.41~].  cramers_v(M) #> Cramer's V |       95% CI #> ------------------------- #> 0.24       | [0.19, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].  pearsons_c(M) #> Pearson's C |       95% CI #> -------------------------- #> 0.32        | [0.26, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].   ## 2-by-2 tables ## ------------- RCT <-   matrix(c(71, 30,            50, 100), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE,          dimnames = list(            Diagnosis = c("Sick", "Recovered"),            Group = c("Treatment", "Control"))) RCT # note groups are COLUMNS #>            Group #> Diagnosis   Treatment Control #>   Sick             71      30 #>   Recovered        50     100  oddsratio(RCT) #> Odds ratio |       95% CI #> ------------------------- #> 4.73       | [2.74, 8.17] oddsratio(RCT, alternative = "greater") #> Odds ratio |      95% CI #> ------------------------ #> 4.73       | [3.00, Inf] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [Inf].  riskratio(RCT) #> Risk ratio |       95% CI #> ------------------------- #> 2.54       | [1.87, 3.45]  cohens_h(RCT) #> Cohen's h |       95% CI #> ------------------------ #> 0.74      | [0.50, 0.99]    ## Dependent (Paired) Contingency Tables ## ------------------------------------- Performance <-   matrix(c(794, 150,            86, 570), nrow = 2,          dimnames = list(            "1st Survey" = c("Approve", "Disapprove"),            "2nd Survey" = c("Approve", "Disapprove"))) Performance #>             2nd Survey #> 1st Survey   Approve Disapprove #>   Approve        794         86 #>   Disapprove     150        570  cohens_g(Performance) #> Cohen's g |       95% CI #> ------------------------ #> 0.14      | [0.07, 0.19]

title: Effect size for non-parametric (rank sum) tests — rank_biserial
text: rank-biserial correlation appropriate non-parametric tests differences - one sample paired samples case, normally tested Wilcoxon's Signed Rank Test (giving matched-pairs rank-biserial correlation) two independent samples case, normally tested Mann-Whitney's U Test (giving Glass' rank-biserial correlation). See stats::wilcox.test. cases, correlation represents difference proportion favorable unfavorable pairs / signed ranks (Kerby, 2014). Values range -1 (values second sample larger values first sample) +1 (values second sample smaller values first sample). Cliff's delta alias rank-biserial correlation two sample case.  rank epsilon squared appropriate non-parametric tests differences 2 samples (rank based ANOVA). See stats::kruskal.test. Values range 0 1, larger values indicating larger differences groups.  Kendall's W appropriate non-parametric tests differences 2 dependent samples (rank based rmANOVA), group (e.g., experimental condition) measured block (e.g., subject). measure also common measure reliability rankings groups raters (blocks). See stats::friedman.test. Values range 0 1, larger values indicating larger differences groups / higher agreement raters.

code: # \donttest{ data(mtcars) mtcars$am <- factor(mtcars$am) mtcars$cyl <- factor(mtcars$cyl)  # Rank Biserial Correlation # =========================  # Two Independent Samples ---------- (rb <- rank_biserial(mpg ~ am, data = mtcars)) #> r (rank biserial) |         95% CI #> ---------------------------------- #> -0.66             | [-0.84, -0.36] # Same as: # rank_biserial("mpg", "am", data = mtcars) # rank_biserial(mtcars$mpg[mtcars$am=="0"], mtcars$mpg[mtcars$am=="1"])  # More options: rank_biserial(mpg ~ am, data = mtcars, mu = -5) #> r (rank biserial) |        95% CI #> --------------------------------- #> -0.21             | [-0.56, 0.20] #>  #> - Deviation from a difference of -5. print(rb, append_CLES = TRUE) #> r (rank biserial) |         95% CI #> ---------------------------------- #> -0.66             | [-0.84, -0.36] #>  #>  #> ## Common Language Effect Sizes: #> Parameter       | Coefficient |       95% CI #> -------------------------------------------- #> Pr(superiority) |        0.17 | [0.08, 0.32] #>  #> -  #> - Non-parametric CLES #> - cyan   # One Sample ---------- rank_biserial(wt ~ 1, data = mtcars, mu = 3) #> r (rank biserial) |        95% CI #> --------------------------------- #> 0.21              | [-0.18, 0.54] #>  #> - Deviation from a difference of 3. # same as: # rank_biserial("wt", data = mtcars, mu = 3) # rank_biserial(mtcars$wt, mu = 3)   # Paired Samples ---------- dat <- data.frame(Cond1 = c(1.83, 0.5, 1.62, 2.48, 1.68, 1.88, 1.55, 3.06, 1.3),                   Cond2 = c(0.878, 0.647, 0.598, 2.05, 1.06, 1.29, 1.06, 3.14, 1.29)) (rb <- rank_biserial(Pair(Cond1, Cond2) ~ 1, data = dat, paired = TRUE)) #> r (rank biserial) |       95% CI #> -------------------------------- #> 0.78              | [0.30, 0.94]  # same as: # rank_biserial(dat$Cond1, dat$Cond2, paired = TRUE)  interpret_rank_biserial(0.78) #> [1] "very large" #> (Rules: funder2019) #>  interpret(rb, rules = "funder2019") #> r (rank biserial) |       95% CI | Interpretation #> ------------------------------------------------- #> 0.78              | [0.30, 0.94] |     very large #>  #> - Interpretation rule: funder2019   # Rank Epsilon Squared # ====================  rank_epsilon_squared(mpg ~ cyl, data = mtcars) #> Epsilon2 (rank) |       95% CI #> ------------------------------ #> 0.83            | [0.79, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].    # Kendall's W # =========== dat <- data.frame(cond = c("A", "B", "A", "B", "A", "B"),                   ID = c("L", "L", "M", "M", "H", "H"),                   y = c(44.56, 28.22, 24, 28.78, 24.56, 18.78)) (W <- kendalls_w(y ~ cond | ID, data = dat, verbose = FALSE)) #> Kendall's W |       95% CI #> -------------------------- #> 0.11        | [0.11, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].  interpret_kendalls_w(0.11) #> [1] "slight agreement" #> (Rules: landis1977) #>  interpret(W, rules = "landis1977") #> Kendall's W |       95% CI |   Interpretation #> --------------------------------------------- #> 0.11        | [0.11, 1.00] | slight agreement #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. #> - Interpretation rule: landis1977 # }

title: Parameters standardization — standardize_parameters
text: Compute standardized model parameters (coefficients).

title: Parameters standardization — standardize_parameters
code: standardize_parameters(   model,   method = "refit",   ci = 0.95,   robust = FALSE,   two_sd = FALSE,   include_response = TRUE,   verbose = TRUE,   parameters,   ... )  standardize_posteriors(   model,   method = "refit",   robust = FALSE,   two_sd = FALSE,   include_response = TRUE,   verbose = TRUE,   ... )

title: Parameters standardization — standardize_parameters
text: model statistical model. method method used standardizing parameters. Can "refit" (default), "posthoc", "smart", "basic" "pseudo". See 'Details'. ci Confidence Interval (CI) level robust Logical, TRUE, centering done subtracting median variables dividing median absolute deviation (MAD). FALSE, variables standardized subtracting mean dividing standard deviation (SD). two_sd TRUE, variables scaled two times deviation (SD MAD depending robust). method can useful obtain model coefficients continuous parameters comparable coefficients related binary predictors, applied predictors (outcome) (Gelman, 2008). include_response TRUE (default), response value also standardized. FALSE, predictors standardized. GLMs response value never standardized (see Generalized Linear Models section). verbose Toggle warnings messages . parameters Deprecated. ... standardize_parameters(), arguments passed parameters::model_parameters, : ci_method, centrality Mixed models Bayesian models... exponentiate, ... etc.

title: Parameters standardization — standardize_parameters
text: data frame standardized parameters (Std_*, depending model type) CIs (CI_low CI_high). applicable, standard errors (SEs) returned attribute (attr(x, "standard_error")).

title: Parameters standardization — standardize_parameters
text: refit: method based complete model re-fit standardized version data. Hence, method equal standardizing variables fitting model. "purest" accurate (Neter et al., 1989), also computationally costly long (especially heavy models Bayesian models). method particularly recommended complex models include interactions transformations (e.g., polynomial spline terms). robust (default FALSE) argument enables robust standardization data, .e., based median MAD instead mean SD. See standardize() details. Note standardize_parameters(method = "refit") may return results fitting model data standardized standardize(); standardize_parameters() used data used model fitting function, might data missing values. see remove_na argument standardize(). posthoc: Post-hoc standardization parameters, aiming emulating results obtained "refit" without refitting model. coefficients divided standard deviation (MAD robust) outcome (becomes expression 'unit'). , coefficients related numeric variables additionally multiplied standard deviation (MAD robust) related terms, correspond changes 1 SD predictor (e.g., "change 1 SD x related change 0.24 SD y). apply binary variables factors, coefficients still related changes levels. method accurate tend give aberrant results interactions specified. basic: method similar method = "posthoc", treats variables continuous: also scales coefficient standard deviation model's matrix' parameter factors levels (transformed integers) binary predictors. Although inappropriate cases, method one implemented default software packages, lm.beta::lm.beta(). smart (Standardization Model's parameters Adjustment, Reconnaissance Transformation - experimental): Similar method = "posthoc" involve model refitting. difference SD (MAD robust) response computed relevant section data. instance, factor 3 levels (intercept), B C entered predictor, effect corresponding B vs. scaled variance response intercept . results, coefficients effects factors similar Glass' delta. pseudo (2-level (G)LMMs ): (post-hoc) method, response predictor standardized based level prediction (levels detected performance::check_heterogeneity_bias()): Predictors standardized based SD level prediction (see also datawizard::demean()); outcome (linear LMMs) standardized based fitted random-intercept-model, sqrt(random-intercept-variance) used level 2 predictors, sqrt(residual-variance) used level 1 predictors (Hoffman 2015, page 342). warning given within-group varialbe found access -group variance.

title: Parameters standardization — standardize_parameters
text: model's formula contains transformations (e.g. y ~ exp(X)) method = "refit" give different results compared method = "basic" ("posthoc" "smart" support transformations): "refit" standardizes data prior transformation (e.g. equivalent exp(scale(X))), "basic" method standardizes transformed data (e.g. equivalent scale(exp(X))).  See Transformed Variables section standardize.default() details different transformations dealt method = "refit".

title: Parameters standardization — standardize_parameters
code: library(effectsize)  model <- lm(len ~ supp * dose, data = ToothGrowth) standardize_parameters(model, method = "refit") #> # Standardization method: refit #>  #> Parameter   | Coefficient (std.) |         95% CI #> ------------------------------------------------- #> (Intercept) |               0.24 | [ 0.05,  0.44] #> suppVC      |              -0.48 | [-0.76, -0.21] #> dose        |               0.64 | [ 0.45,  0.84] #> suppVC:dose |               0.32 | [ 0.04,  0.60] # \donttest{ standardize_parameters(model, method = "posthoc") #> # Standardization method: posthoc #>  #> Parameter   | Coefficient (std.) |         95% CI #> ------------------------------------------------- #> (Intercept) |               0.00 | [ 0.00,  0.00] #> suppVC      |              -1.08 | [-1.66, -0.49] #> dose        |               0.64 | [ 0.45,  0.84] #> suppVC:dose |               0.32 | [ 0.04,  0.60] standardize_parameters(model, method = "smart") #> # Standardization method: smart #>  #> Parameter   | Coefficient (std.) |         95% CI #> ------------------------------------------------- #> (Intercept) |               0.00 | [ 0.00,  0.00] #> suppVC      |              -1.00 | [-1.54, -0.46] #> dose        |               0.64 | [ 0.45,  0.84] #> suppVC:dose |               0.55 | [ 0.07,  1.02] standardize_parameters(model, method = "basic") #> # Standardization method: basic #>  #> Parameter   | Coefficient (std.) |         95% CI #> ------------------------------------------------- #> (Intercept) |               0.00 | [ 0.00,  0.00] #> suppVC      |              -0.54 | [-0.84, -0.25] #> dose        |               0.64 | [ 0.45,  0.84] #> suppVC:dose |               0.38 | [ 0.05,  0.70]  # Robust and 2 SD standardize_parameters(model, robust = TRUE) #> # Standardization method: refit #>  #> Parameter   | Coefficient (std.) |         95% CI #> ------------------------------------------------- #> (Intercept) |               0.01 | [-0.16,  0.18] #> suppVC      |              -0.48 | [-0.72, -0.24] #> dose        |               0.64 | [ 0.44,  0.84] #> suppVC:dose |               0.32 | [ 0.04,  0.60] #>  #> - Scaled by one MAD from the median. standardize_parameters(model, two_sd = TRUE) #> # Standardization method: refit #>  #> Parameter   | Coefficient (std.) |         95% CI #> ------------------------------------------------- #> (Intercept) |               0.24 | [ 0.05,  0.44] #> suppVC      |              -0.48 | [-0.76, -0.21] #> dose        |               1.28 | [ 0.89,  1.68] #> suppVC:dose |               0.64 | [ 0.09,  1.20] #>  #> - Scaled by two SDs from the mean.   model <- glm(am ~ cyl * mpg, data = mtcars, family = "binomial") standardize_parameters(model, method = "refit") #> # Standardization method: refit #>  #> Parameter   | Coefficient (std.) |        95% CI #> ------------------------------------------------ #> (Intercept) |              -0.58 | [-1.98, 0.70] #> cyl         |               0.25 | [-1.54, 2.10] #> mpg         |               2.10 | [-0.19, 5.28] #> cyl:mpg     |              -0.36 | [-2.57, 1.54] #>  #> - Response is unstandardized. standardize_parameters(model, method = "posthoc") #> # Standardization method: posthoc #>  #> Parameter   | Coefficient (std.) |         95% CI #> ------------------------------------------------- #> (Intercept) |               0.00 | [ 0.00,  0.00] #> cyl         |               1.46 | [-4.63,  9.37] #> mpg         |               3.36 | [-2.31, 12.59] #> cyl:mpg     |              -0.20 | [-1.44,  0.86] #>  #> - Response is unstandardized. standardize_parameters(model, method = "basic", exponentiate = TRUE) #> # Standardization method: basic #>  #> Parameter   | Odds Ratio (std.) |           95% CI #> -------------------------------------------------- #> (Intercept) |              1.00 | [1.00,     1.00] #> cyl         |              4.32 | [0.01, 11681.98] #> mpg         |             28.80 | [0.10, 2.92e+05] #> cyl:mpg     |              0.54 | [0.01,    13.94] #>  #> - Response is unstandardized. # }   # \donttest{ m <- lme4::lmer(mpg ~ cyl + am + vs + (1 | cyl), mtcars) #> boundary (singular) fit: see help('isSingular') standardize_parameters(m, method = "pseudo", ci_method = "satterthwaite") #> Warning: The following within-group terms have between-group variance: #> 	am, vs #> This can inflate standardized within-group parameters associated with #> these terms. See help("demean", package = "datawizard") for modeling #> between- and within-subject effects. #> # Standardization method: pseudo #>  #> Parameter   | Coefficient (std.) |         95% CI #> ------------------------------------------------- #> (Intercept) |               0.00 | [ 0.00,  0.00] #> cyl         |              -0.74 | [-1.25, -0.23] #> am          |               0.47 | [-0.01,  0.95] #> vs          |               0.20 | [-0.50,  0.90] # }  if (FALSE) { model <- stanarm::stan_glm(rating ~ critical + privileges, data = attitude, refresh = 0) standardize_posteriors(model, method = "refit") standardize_posteriors(model, method = "posthoc") standardize_posteriors(model, method = "smart") head(standardize_posteriors(model, method = "basic")) }

title:
Convert test statistics (t, z, F) to effect sizes of differences (Cohen's d)
or association (partial r) — t_to_d
text: functions use following formulae approximate r d:  $$r_{partial} = t / \sqrt{t^2 + df_{error}}$$  $$r_{partial} = z / \sqrt{z^2 + N}$$  $$d = 2 * t / \sqrt{df_{error}}$$  $$d_z = t / \sqrt{df_{error}}$$  $$d = 2 * z / \sqrt{N}$$ resulting d effect size approximation Cohen's d, assumes two equal group sizes. possible, advised directly estimate Cohen's d, cohens_d(), emmeans::eff_size(), similar functions.

code: ## t Tests res <- t.test(1:10, y = c(7:20), var.equal = TRUE) t_to_d(t = res$statistic, res$parameter) #> d     |         95% CI #> ---------------------- #> -2.19 | [-3.23, -1.12] t_to_r(t = res$statistic, res$parameter) #> r     |         95% CI #> ---------------------- #> -0.74 | [-0.85, -0.49] t_to_r(t = res$statistic, res$parameter, alternative = "less") #> r     |         95% CI #> ---------------------- #> -0.74 | [-1.00, -0.54] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: lower bound fixed at [-1.00].  res <- with(sleep, t.test(extra[group == 1], extra[group == 2], paired = TRUE)) t_to_d(t = res$statistic, res$parameter, paired = TRUE) #> d     |         95% CI #> ---------------------- #> -1.35 | [-2.23, -0.44] t_to_r(t = res$statistic, res$parameter) #> r     |         95% CI #> ---------------------- #> -0.80 | [-0.91, -0.40] t_to_r(t = res$statistic, res$parameter, alternative = "greater") #> r     |        95% CI #> --------------------- #> -0.80 | [-0.90, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].  # \donttest{ ## Linear Regression model <- lm(rating ~ complaints + critical, data = attitude) (param_tab <- parameters::model_parameters(model)) #> Parameter   | Coefficient |    SE |         95% CI | t(27) |      p #> ------------------------------------------------------------------- #> (Intercept) |       14.25 | 11.17 | [-8.67, 37.18] |  1.28 | 0.213  #> complaints  |        0.75 |  0.10 | [ 0.55,  0.96] |  7.46 | < .001 #> critical    |    1.91e-03 |  0.14 | [-0.28,  0.28] |  0.01 | 0.989  #>  #> Uncertainty intervals (equal-tailed) and p values (two-tailed) computed using a #>   Wald t-distribution approximation.  (rs <- t_to_r(param_tab$t[2:3], param_tab$df_error[2:3])) #> r        |        95% CI #> ------------------------ #> 0.82     | [ 0.67, 0.89] #> 2.70e-03 | [-0.35, 0.36]  if (require(see)) plot(rs)   # How does this compare to actual partial correlations? if (require("correlation")) {   correlation::correlation(attitude[, c(1, 2, 6)], partial = TRUE)[1:2, c(2, 3, 7, 8)] } #> Loading required package: correlation #> Parameter2 |        r | t(28) #> ----------------------------- #> complaints |     0.82 |  7.60 #> critical   | 2.70e-03 |  0.01 # }

title: effectsize 0.6.0.3
text: kendalls_w() now deals ties. eta_squared() works car::Manova() -design.

title: effectsize 0.6.0.3
text: Support insight’s display, print_md print_html effectsize outputs.

title: effectsize 0.6.0.1
text: CRAN release: 2022-01-26 patch release.

title: effectsize 0.6.0.1
text: interpret.performance_lavaan() now works without attaching effectsize ( #410 ). eta_squared() now fully support multi-variate car ANOVAs (class Anova.mlm; #406 ).

title: effectsize 0.6.0
text: CRAN release: 2022-01-14

title: effectsize 0.6.0
text: pearsons_c() effect size column name changed Pearsons_c consistency.

title: effectsize 0.6.0
text: See Support functions model extensions vignette.

title: effectsize 0.6.0
text: eta_squared() family now supports afex::mixed() models. cles() estimating common language effect sizes. rb_to_cles() converting rank-biserial correlation Probability superiority.

title: effectsize 0.6.0
text: effectsize() BayesFactor objects returns standardized output htest.

title: effectsize 0.6.0
text: eta_squared() MLM return effect sizes correct order responses. eta_squared() family longer fails CIs fail due non-finite Fs / degrees freedom. standardize() multivariate models standardizes (multivariate) response. standardize() models offsets standardizes offset variables according include_response two_sd ( #396 ). eta_squared(): fixed bug caused afex_aov models 2 within-subject factors return incorrect effect sizes lower level factors ( #389 ).

title: effectsize 0.5.0
text: cramers_v() correctly work 1-dimentional tables (goodness--fit tests). interpret_d(), interpret_g(), interpret_delta() now interpret_cohens_d(), interpret_hedges_g(), interpret_glass_delta(). interpret_parameters() removed. Use interpret_r() instead (caution!). Phi, Cohen’s w, Cramer’s V, ANOVA effect sizes, rank Epsilon squared, Kendall’s W - CIs default 95% one-sided CIs (alternative = "greater"). (restore previous behavior, set ci = .9, alternative = "two.sided".) adjust(), change_scale(), normalize(), ranktransform(), standardize() (data), unstandardize() moved new {datawizard} package!

title: effectsize 0.5.0
text: pearsons_c() (chisq_to_pearsons_c()) estimating Pearson’s contingency coefficient. interpret_vif() interpretation variance inflation factors. oddsratio_to_riskratio() can now convert coefficients RR coefficients logistic GLM(M). effect-size functions gain alternative argument can used make one- two-sided CIs. interpret() now accepts input results cohens_d(), eta_squared(), rank_biserial(), etc. interpret_pd() interpretation Probability Direction.

title: effectsize 0.5.0
text: kendalls_w() CIs now correctly bootstrap samples raw data (previously rank-transformed data sampled ). cohens_d(), sd_pooled() rank_biserial() now properly respect y grouping character vector. effectsize() Chi-squared test goodness--fit now correctly respects non-uniform expected probabilities ( #352 ).

title: effectsize 0.5.0
text: interpret_bf() now accepts log(BF) input.

title: effectsize 0.4.5
text: CRAN release: 2021-05-25

title: effectsize 0.4.5
text: eta_squared() family now indicate type sum--squares used. rank_biserial() estimates CIs using normal approximation (previously used bootstrapping). hedges_g() now used exact bias correction (thanks @mdelacre suggestion!) glass_delta() now estimates CIs using NCP method based Algina et al (2006).

title: effectsize 0.4.5
text: eta_squared() family returns correctly returns type 2/3 effect sizes mixed ANOVAs fit afex. cohens_d() family now correctly deals missing factor levels ( #318 ) cohens_d() / hedges_g() minor fix CI unequal variances.

title: effectsize 0.4.5
text: mad_pooled() (robust version sd_pooled()) now correctly pools two samples.

title: effectsize 0.4.4-1
text: CRAN release: 2021-04-05

title: effectsize 0.4.4-1
text: standardize_parameters() + eta_sqaured() support tidymodels (underlying model supported; #311 ). cohens_d() family now supports Pairs() objects input. standardize_parameters() gains include_response argument (default TRUE) ( #309 ).

title: effectsize 0.4.4-1
text: kendalls_w() now actually returns correct effect size. Previous estimates incorrect, based transposing groups blocks.

title: effectsize 0.4.4
text: CRAN release: 2021-03-14 effectsize now supports R >= 3.4.

title: effectsize 0.4.4
text: standardize_parameters() now supports bootstrapped estimates (parameters::bootstrap_model() parameters::bootstrap_parameters()). unstandardize() reverse effects standardize(). interpret_kendalls_w() interpret Kendall’s coefficient concordance. eta_squared() family functions can now also return effect sizes intercept setting include_intercept = TRUE ( #156 ).

title: effectsize 0.4.4
text: standardize() can now deal dates ( #300 ).

title: effectsize 0.4.3
text: CRAN release: 2021-01-18

title: effectsize 0.4.3
text: oddsratio() riskratio() - order groups changed (first groups now treatment group, second group control group), effect sizes given treatment control (treatment / control) (previously reversed). done consistent functions R effectsize.

title: effectsize 0.4.3
text: cohens_h() effect size comparing two independent proportions. rank_biserial(), cliffs_delta(), rank_epsilon_squared() kendalls_w() functions effect sizes rank-based tests. adjust() gains keep_intercept argument keep intercept. eta_squared() family functions supports Anova.mlm objects (car package). effectsize(): supports Cohen’s g McNemar’s test. Extracts Fisher’s Exact Test 2x2 case. eta2_to_f2() / f2_to_eta2() convert two types effect sizes ANOVA ( #240 ). cohens_d() family functions gain mu argument.

title: effectsize 0.4.3
text: adjust() properly works multilevel = TRUE. cohens_d() family / sd_pooled() now properly fails given missing column name.

title: effectsize 0.4.3
text: effectsize() htest objects now tries first extract data used testing, computed effect size directly data. cohens_d() family / sd_pooled() now respect transformations (e.g. (log(x) - 3) ~ factor(y)) passed formula. eta_squared() family functions gains verbose argument. verbose argument strictly respected. glass_delta() returns CIs based bootstrap.

title: effectsize 0.4.1
text: CRAN release: 2020-12-07

title: effectsize 0.4.1
text: cohens_d() glass_delta(): correction argument deprecated, favor correctly implemented hedges_g() ( #222 ). eta_squared_posterior() longer uses car::Anova() default.

title: effectsize 0.4.1
text: effectsize() gains type = argument specifying effect size return. eta_squared_posterior() can return generalized Eta squared. oddsratio() riskratio() functions 2--2 contingency tables. standardize() gains support mediation::mediate() models. eta_squared() family available manova objects.

title: effectsize 0.4.1
text: eta_squared() family functions returns non-partial effect size one-way subjects design (#180).

title: effectsize 0.4.1
text: hedges_g() correctly implements available bias correction methods ( #222 ). Fixed width CI Cohen’s d Hedges’ g using non-pooled SD.

title: effectsize 0.4.0
text: CRAN release: 2020-10-25

title: effectsize 0.4.0
text: standardize_parameters() multi-component models (zero-inflated) now returns unstandardized parameters cases standardization possible (previously returned NAs). Column name changes: eta_squared() / F_to_eta2 families function now Eta2 format, previously Eta_Sq. cramers_v now Cramers_v

title: effectsize 0.4.0
text: effectsize() added support BayesFactor objects (Cohen’s d, Cramer’s v, r). cohens_g() effect size paired contingency tables. Generalized Eta Squared now available via eta_squared(generalized = ...). eta_squared(), omega_squared() epsilon_squared() fully support aovlist, afex_aov mlm (maov) objects. standardize_parameters() can now return Odds ratios / IRRs (exponentiated parameter) setting exponentiate = TRUE. Added cohens_f_squared() F_to_f2() Cohen’s f-squared. cohens_f() / cohens_f_squared()can used estimate Cohen’s f R-squared change two models. standardize() standardize_info() work weighted models / data ( #82 ). Added hardlyworking (simulated) dataset, use examples. interpret_* ( #131 ): interpret_omega_squared() added "cohen1992" rule. interpret_p() added Redefine statistical significance rules. oddsratio_to_riskratio() converting RR.

title: effectsize 0.4.0
text: CIs Omega-/Epsilon-squared Adjusted Phi/Cramer’s V return 0s instead negative values. standardize() data frames gains remove_na argument dealing NAs ( #147 ). standardize() standardize_info() now (extension, standardize_parameters()) respect weights weighted models standardizing ( #82 ). Internal changes standardize_parameters() (reducing co-dependency parameters) - argument parameters dropped.

title: effectsize 0.4.0
text: ranktransform(sign = TURE) correctly (doesn’t) deal zeros. effectsize() htest works Spearman Kendall correlations ( #165 ). cramers_v() phi() now work goodness--fit data ( #158 ) standardize_parameters() post-hoc correctly standardizes transformed outcome. Setting two_sd = TRUE standardize() standardize_parameters() (correctly) uses 2-SDs predictors (response). standardize_info() / standardize_parameters(method = "posthoc") work zero-inflated models ( #135 ) standardize_info(include_pseudo = TRUE) / standardize_parameters(method = "pseudo") less sensitive detecting -group variation within-group variables. interpret_oddsratio() correctly treats extremely small odds treats extremely large ones.

title: effectsize 0.3.3
text: CRAN release: 2020-09-17

title: effectsize 0.3.3
text: standardize_parameters(method = "pseudo") returns pseudo-standardized coefficients (G)LMM models. d_to_common_language() common language measures standardized differences (-la Cohen’s d).

title: effectsize 0.3.3
text: r_to_odds() family now deprecated favor r_to_oddsratio(). interpret_odds() now deprecated favor interpret_oddsratio()

title: effectsize 0.3.3
text: phi() cramers_v() respect CI argument ( #111 ). standardize() / standardize_parameters() properly deal transformed data model formula ( #113 ). odds_to_probs() mis-treating impossible odds (NEVER TELL ODDS! #123 )

title: effectsize 0.3.2
text: CRAN release: 2020-07-27

title: effectsize 0.3.2
text: eta_squared_posterior() estimating Eta Squared Bayesian models. eta_squared(), omega_squared() epsilon_squared() now works ols / rms models. effectsize() class htest supports oneway.test(...).

title: effectsize 0.3.2
text: Fix minor miss-calculation Chi-squared 2*2 table small samples ( #102 ). Fixed miss-calculation signed rank ranktransform() ( #87 ). Fixed bug standardize() standard objects non-standard class-attributes (like vectors class haven_labelled vctrs_vctr). Fix effectsize() one sample t.test(...) ( #95 ; thanks pull request @mutlusun )

title: effectsize 0.3.1
text: CRAN release: 2020-05-19

title: effectsize 0.3.1
text: standardize_parameters() now returns CIs ( #72 ) eta_squared(), omega_squared() epsilon_squared() now works gam models. afex models. lme anova.lme objects. New function equivalence_test() effect sizes. New plotting methods see package.

title: effectsize 0.3.0
text: CRAN release: 2020-04-11

title: effectsize 0.3.0
text: New general purpose effectsize() function. Effectsize differences CI methods, return data frame. Effectsize ANOVA CI methods, none based bootstrapping. New effect sizes contingency tables (phi() cramers_v()). chisq_to_phi() / cramers_v() functions now support CIs (via ncp method), return data frame. F_to_eta2() family functions now support CIs (via ncp method), return data frame. t_to_d() t_to_r() now support CIs (via ncp method), return data frame. standardize() model-objects default-method, usually accepts models. Exception model-objects work added missing. standardize.data.frame() gets append suffix arguments, add (instead replace) standardized variables returned data frame. eta_squared(), omega_squared() epsilon_squared() now works output parameters::model_parameters(). mlm models.

title: effectsize 0.3.0
text: Fix cohens_d()’s dealing formula input (#44). sd_pooled() now returns … pooled sd (#44).

title: effectsize 0.3.0
text: t_to_d(), argument pooled now paired.

title: effectsize 0.2.0
text: standardize.data.frame() work variables missing values. Fixed wrong computation standardize() two_sd = TRUE. Fixed bug missing column names standardize_parameters() models different components (like count zero-inflation).
